characters: THE SPINNING WHEEL OF A TRUCK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A handful of people are gathered in an open field under a fierce Mississippi sun. A couple of young inmates, JAKE a LEON, lean on their shovels. They are waiting to bury two identical CASKETS with inmate numbers stenciled on the  pinewood lids. A GUARD rests the butt of his rifle on the ground and tak a long, healthy pull from his canteen. He offers it to th PRISON CHAPLAIN, who is much obliged. SUPERINTENDENT BILL BURKE, a 40-year-old black man, glances at his watch and  loosens his tie. Sure is hot. MARY HUMPHRIES, an elderly white woman in a nurse's unifo stands behind WILLIE LONG, an ancient inmate sleeping  peacefully in a wheelchair. She readjusts an umbrella to  shield the old black man from the blistering sun. Burke dabs his forehead with a handkerchief. He gives the nod to the chaplain, who steps forward and cracks his bib The men remove their hats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In accordance with the regulations  of the State of Mississippi, we gather  here today to lay to rest the remains  of inmates R. Gibson, number 4316,  and C. Banks, number 4317. Ashes to  ashes, dust to dust. May God have  mercy on their souls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, fellas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young inmates plunge their shovels into the dirt. One one, the mourners head back toward a prison van parked on nearby dirt road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come back for you in a little  while, Willie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves Willie alone with Jake and Leon. He rolls his  chair up to the edge of the graves and gazes at the pinew caskets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These two guys friends of yours, old  man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We spent some time together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do I get the feeling when you  say some time, you mean some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was already here a good many years  when they came in in 1932.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1932? That's like, that's like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty-five years ago. They always  said the farm couldn't hold 'em  forever. Looks like you're finally  free, boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie pulls a bottle of moonshine from his jacket and ta a swig in their honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, the dude's holdin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, old-timer, hook the brothers  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie passes the bottle to Leon, who takes a swig and wi from the unexpected kick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell of a way to get out. Heard they  burned up in that fire yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I seen the bodies before they sealed  'em up. Them fellas sizzled up good.  Looked like some shit from the X- Files. (taking a swig from  the bottle) Damn, that shit's nasty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's special recipe. He always had  exacting standards where the hooch  was concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were they, bootleggers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie holds up the bottle, checking the clarity of the  liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAY GIBSON holds up a similar bottle of liquor to a light over a door. Music comes from within. He takes a swig and stashes the bottle in his belt. He adjusts his tie, polis his shoes on the back of his pants and raps on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The speakeasy is jumping, jammed with people. Up on stage hot JAZZ BAND is playing backup for a seductive CHANTEUSE Well-heeled PATRONS enter through doors near the stage. In the back, at the end of a long hallway, a BOUNCER crac open the door and Ray squeezes inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Ray. Not tonight. Spanky's  not happy with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Spanky here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what's the problem?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do yourself a favor and find another  place where they let you in the front  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this is where the action is and  I have to be where the action is.  Look, when your old lady wanted those  alligator shoes, didn't I come through  for you? Ain't she stepping in style  now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, alright then. What do you think  about this new tie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look good tonight. And I feel lucky,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone asks, it wasn't me who let  you in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray slides through the crowd, pausing at the bar to nibbl on the neck of a COCKTAIL WAITRESS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even try it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When do you get off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I get off at two, but you ain't never  getting off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She carries a tray of drinks into the crowd. Ray shakes h head in wonderment at her departing form. The BARKEEP ste up as Ray pulls out his bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't drink that in here, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure can't drink that watered-down  swill you're serving. Give me a glass  of ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't give you a glass of ice. I  can't give you anything until you  pay your damn tab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disregarding the warning, Ray tilts the bottle back. Shak his head, the barkeep moves on to a paying customer. Ray' eyes follow a bottle of French Champagne as it is deliver to a nearby table. Here sits the straight-laced CLAUDE BANKS with his girlfr DAISY. She's enjoying the show. He's polishing the silver The WAITER pours two glasses of champagne and leaves the  bottle on ice. Claude regards his glass skeptically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the kind of money they charge  here, you'd think they could hire  somebody to actually wash the dishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude. Here's to your new job down  at the bank. I always knew you'd  make something of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Know what I'm going to buy with my  first pay check?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy thinks she does. She leans in, eyes twinkling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Season tickets to the Yankees. Right  there on the first base line. (off her disappointment) What's wrong, baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping you were gonna say an  engagement ring, Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French Champagne shoots out of Claude's nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engagement ring!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what respectable folks do.  Get a job, get married, start having  babies. That's what you want, isn't  it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure it is. I just don't see any  reason to rush into things. Damn,  look at this shirt. I'll be right  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude leans in to kiss Daisy on the lips. She offers her cheek. He departs.

dialogues.speaker: OVER BY THE BAR
dialogues.text: Ray watches Claude make a beeline for the men's room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude steps into the bathroom and approaches the sink. A big hand falls on his shoulder and yanks him backwards in a stall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude is shoved down on the toilet by two BAG MEN in sui Suddenly, it's crowded in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations, Claude. We understand  you finally got yourself a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess that means you can pay Mr.  Riley the fifty bucks you owe him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They rifle through Claude's jacket and quickly find his  wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now wait a second, guys. I've got a  bill to pay out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-two dollars. Not bad for a  start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They toss back his empty wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, fellas, that's two weeks  pay. I'm here with my girl. You gotta  leave me something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about your legs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My legs? Those are good, I'll keep  the legs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The stall door swings shut as the bag men depart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On his way into the Men's Room, Ray squeezes past the bag men on their way out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glancing around, Ray spots Claude's feet under the stall  door. He steps up to the sink, washes his hands and takes towel from the ATTENDANT. Scanning the assortment of groo products, he selects a bottle of cologne and takes a snif

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (displeased) You have any of that French stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the attendent bends down to retrieve a bottle of the g stuff, Ray palms a coin from the tip basket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray offers the quarter, a gesture of uncommon generosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep the change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, thank you, sir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray pats the cologne on his face. A toilet flushes and Cl steps over to the sink. Ray catches his eye in the mirror

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't I know you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I do. What's your name again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude Banks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude Banks. How could I forget  that? You've got to remember me. Ray  Gibson. We went to high school  together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went to Monroe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beaming) That's right! Good old Monroe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray throws his arms around Claude, deftly snatching his  wallet. Claude extracts himself from Ray's embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I went to Jefferson, so you  must have a different Claude Banks  in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude straightens his jacket and heads for the door. Ray stashes the stolen wallet in his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, man. My mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the stage, the chanteuse has downshifted into a sultry number about back-door lovers and broken dreams. Ray steps out of the men's room and is instantly collared BULLETHEAD, a man who makes his living being large and  threatening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch the threads, Bullethead. If  this is about my tab, I've got it  covered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pressed up against the wall, Ray reaches into his jacket produces Claude's wallet. Bullethead snatches it, inspect it and is not impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This ain't about your tab, Ray. You've  got bigger problems than that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stuffs the wallet back into Ray's jacket and hustles R out the back door past the bouncer who let him in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Ray Gibson? Who the hell let  him in here?

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT CLAUDE'S TABLE
dialogues.text: Claude returns to the table where Daisy is sipping champa He takes the glass out of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, honey, let's get out of  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm having a good time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sir, I believe you forgot  this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter presents Claude with the bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bill. Of course, the bill. We  couldn't leave without paying the  bill. Especially such an incredibly  large bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude is shoved into the back of the van and the doors a slammed behind him. He bangs and shouts, but it's no use.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save your energy, Claude. You're  gonna need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is stretched out against the back wall. Claude is kno to the floor as the van lurches into motion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, this belongs to you. (tossing Claude his  wallet) It was empty when I found it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good old Monroe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray swigs from his bottle and offers it to Claude, who is interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I want to know is what happened  to your cush between the time that  you got up from the table and when I  caught up with you in the Johnny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see where that's any of your  business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did those two muscle heads shake you  down? Swear I've seen them down at  the track with Sure-shot Riley. That's  it, ain't it? A gambling debt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busted, Claude snatches the bottle and carefully wipes of the neck before tilting it high. Ray gets a good chuckle of this straight cat in the bow tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where they taking us, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably to Spanky's headquarters  down at the pier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, I'm looking forward to meeting  this Spanky. Give me a chance to  straighten out this whole mess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait to see that. You slay  me, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van pulls into a the loading bay of a warehouse at th end of a short pier on the Harlem River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullethead and a HENCHMAN pull Ray and Claude from the ba of the van. They find themselves in a dark warehouse fill with crates of contraband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) What are they gonna do to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You? Dine and ditch, right? (Claude nods) Over ten bucks? (he nods again) You're probably looking at a thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thumb? What do you mean, like cut  it off? For ten bucks? (Ray nods) That include the tip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude shoves his hands under his armpits at the sound of approaching FOOTSTEPS echoing across the vast space. Clau and Ray peer into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the darkness) You picked the wrong night to fuck  with me, Ray. I just lost three men  and a truck full of Canadian whiskey.  You know what that kind of thing  does to my business? It makes me  want to lash out and hurt somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SPANKY JOHNSON emerges into the light. He uses a small si spoon to take an ample snort of cocaine into each nostril He glances at Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's he? Friend of yours, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never saw this man before tonight.  He's a lowlife degenerate who lurks  in bathrooms. I'm a professional  man, an upstanding citizen. I go to  church on Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Failure to pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rattled) Look, Mr. Johnson, you seem like a  reasonable man. I got a good job  starts Monday. I'll pay you back  with my first pay check. With  interest. I don't want to tell you  how to conduct your business, but if  you cut off my finger you won't get  jack. Working an adding machine, I  gotta be whole. (his fingers dancing  over imaginary keys) I need my thumbs and all my fingers  for praying and doing good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanky holds up a hand, silencing Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The choirboy wants to keep his  fingers. Who am I to argue? Drop  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drop him? What does drop him mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude protests loudly as Bullethead and the henchman bin his hands and feet. Spanky turns to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta lotta balls showing your  face around my club. If a man's gonna  run numbers on my side of Broadway,  you think he'd have the common sense  to keep a low profile. But not Ray  Gibson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The goons hoist Claude up on another pulley and dangle hi head first over a hole in the floor. Several feet down, t Harlem River laps against the wooden pylons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not down there! That water's  filthy! Help me out here, man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shrugging, Ray pinches his nose and puffs out his cheeks. The goons release the rope and Claude plunges into the wa Spanky turns back to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to drown that fella,  Spanky. You already scared him half  to death. He didn't know who he was  fucking with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you do. What does that say about  you, Ray? What does that say about  me? I've given you a lot of leeway  over the years on account of your  father. But he didn't last long enough  to teach you the meaning of the word  respect so I guess I'm gonna have to  school you myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Spank, I'm just trying to  get by here. You remember how it was  when you were starting out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The henchman yanks on the rope. Claude emerges from the h gasping for breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was supposed to wear this suit on  Monday!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The henchman releases the rope, sending Claude back into water. Ray reaches into his jacket. Bullethead pulls a gu and presses it into Ray's temple. Ray gives him a look an cautiously pulls out his bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that, some of your bathtub  brew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Puerto Rican rum. See for yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray tosses him the bottle. Spanky uncorks, sniffs, sample the goods. He's impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comes up the Mississippi. I can get  more. A lot more. I was thinking  about going into business for myself,  but under the circumstances, I'd be  willing to take on a partner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Once again, the henchman yanks on the rope and Claude com up sucking air desperately. He releases the rope, submerg Claude for a third time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm interested. Keep talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I need is the front money and a  truck. I could be back in two, three  days tops if I had somebody to share  the driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanky considers the terms. Can he afford to trust Ray? C he afford not to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you fuck me on this one, I'll  spare no expense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Understood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Ray, you've got a deal.  Pick your man and get going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray glances around. The pulley rope is still twitching in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take the little choirboy, if  you don't mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was you, I'd want somebody who  can handle himself in a tight spot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want somebody who won't put a  bullet in my back once the truck is  full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanky sees Ray's point. He nods to the henchman, who hoi Claude's limp body out of the water and onto the cement.  Spanky plants a foot on Claude's chest and applies pressu A geyser of Harlem River water shoots from Claude's mouth he sputters back to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For your sake, I hope you can drive.  Somebody give him some dry clothes.

dialogues.speaker: THE SPINNING WHEEL OF A TRUCK
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES UP the side of the old Ford truck to fin Claude sitting pensively in the passenger seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray palms the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about that hot sketch you  were hypin' last night. She was a  choice bit of calico. You two been  seeing each other a long time? Gonna  slap the handcuffs on her and stroll  down the aisle one of these days?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight-lipped, Claude shifts in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes I wish I could find me a  sheba to settle down with. Suppose  I'm just a tomcat by nature. (trying to fill the  silence) This little rum run is gonna seriously  improve my relationship with Spanky.  He's a good man to have on your side.  He's got the capital and the  connections. That's what you got to  have in that business. Spanky's place  is pretty plush, but one of these  days I'm gonna open up my own  establishment. Ray's Boom-Boom Room.  You like that? Ray's Boom-Boom Room.  That's in the groove, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Claude does like it, he's not letting on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, daddy-o. You haven't said a  word since we started. Least you  could do is make some friendly  conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, man, I don't want friendly  conversation. I don't want to be  your friend. I've seen your friends  and I don't like them. I just want  to do this thing and get back to New  York in time to start my job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start your job? What kind of job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you must know, bank teller  at First Federal of Manhattan. I'm  responsible for keeping track of  hundreds, occasionally thousands of  dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's some long green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn straight, it is. I got my own  set of keys because I'm supposed to  open up. So if I ain't there 8 a.m.  Monday morning, there's gonna be  hell to pay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat of silence. Ray laughs to himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, tell me what's so funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Bank teller. Sounds  like ladies work to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe I should dig around in  other people's clothes for money.  It's obviously been highly successful  for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you'd be surprised what you  find in other people's pockets. Just  gotta avoid them deadbeat bank  tellers. Get you every time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't start out to be a bank  teller. I was gonna be a ballplayer.  Even had an offer to play short for  the Newark Eagles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Negro League don't pay so good.  And you're always on the road. That  don't wash with Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gave up baseball to be a bank  teller? I can't latch on to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At some point a man's got to get  serious about his future. I'm sure  you have no idea what I'm talking  about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking about giving up  baseball to be a bank teller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bank teller's just a start. I got  plans. Real plans. Not opening some  Zoom-Boom Room. This time next year  I'll be a loan officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loan officer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, a loan officer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you mean, if I needed some jack  to get my nightclub up and running,  I'd have to hype some square like  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray pulls out his pocket watch. A mechanical tune plays a he checks the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would I get a loan, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need collateral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (re: watch) Like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That thing? Who'd you steal it from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daddy gave me this watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Who'd he steal it from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daddy is dead so watch your mouth.  You can say what you want about me,  but don't be dragging my daddy into  it. This watch means the world to  me. Solid gold. Keeps perfect time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like a fake to me. Loan denied!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stuffs his daddy's watch back in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, go chase yourself. I'll take my  business elsewhere. And for future  reference, you are no longer welcome  at Ray's Boom-Boom Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no Boom-Boom Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When there is, you can forget about  it. And I swear to God, you ever  talk about my daddy again I'm gonna  kick your bank-telling, loan-denying  ass, you got me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I liked you better when you  kept your trap shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck veers off the highway and jerks to a halt in fr of the rundown establishment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen WHITE FOLKS look up as Ray and Claude push throug the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, something smells good in here.  How's everybody doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing but sullen stares from all corners of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) Maybe we oughta find another place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? Tell me you don't  want a slice of that pie right over  there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must have left my appetite outside,  which is where I think we ought to  be right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude tugs Ray towards the door but Ray won't be dissuad He boldly addresses a YOUNG MAN in an apron behind the  counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good evening, Billy. We'd like some  coffee and a couple of slices of  that homemade pie you've got  advertised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you know my name's Billy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It says so right there on your shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing down) That what that says?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy's MAMA sets a piping hot pie on the back counter an steps up next to her son. She casts a disparaging glance Claude's suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you boys can read so good, how  come you missed that sign in the  window?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude considers the sign she's pointing to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean this sign? The one that  says "No Coloreds Allowed." That's a  good question. Ray, how come we missed  the sign?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, ma'am, we've been driving all  day. We'd just like to purchase one  of those pies and we'll be on our  way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are whites-only pies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got any nigger pies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude jabs him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any fool could see those are whites- only, not-for-blacks, come-on-let's- get-the-fuck-outta-here pies. Thank  you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude starts tugging Ray toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) Thanks for backing me up here, Uncle  Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) Don't Uncle Claude me. You get a  load of those crackers? Couldn't be  a mouthful of teeth among the bunch  of 'em. Why you want to pick a fight  with people like that for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diner patrons stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said you're soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, don't ever call me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I call it like I see it, and what I  see is definitely soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude narrows his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. You want some pie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I want some pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then, I'm gonna walk over to  that counter and get us some fucking  pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Resolved, Claude stomps over to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, ma'am, I bet a brick will  turn that one right there into a  colored pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude lays down a dollar bill. Mama casually pulls a sho from under the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I bet this right here will turn  you into a colored pie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Ray, I think we can go now.  Much obliged...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gives the whole place a cool once-over as Claude pull him out the door. Mama turns to Billy, still studying the stitching on his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be concentrating so hard, baby.  You're liable to seize yourself again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck rolls up to the waters edge. Ray kills the engi and flashes the lights twice. In the passenger seat, Clau is fast asleep. After a few moments, a FAT MAN appears,  shining a flashlight into the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doing? We're looking for  Slim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You found him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray cocks an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under cover of darkness, a couple of MEN finish loading c into the bed of the truck. Ray and Claude keep their eyes peeled for the law. Down by the river, they can see light and hear music from a district of rowdy juke joints. SLIM steps up, wiping his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it, fellas. Thirty six cases  of Puerto Rico's finest. At five  bucks a case, that's $180.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray pulls out a wad and slaps it in Slim's sweaty palm. T fat man starts counting it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, that music is hot. What goes on  down there, Slim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Natchez-under-the-Hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blacks welcome there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green's the only color that matters  under the hill. They got gambling,  girls. You oughta check it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe we will. Nice meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slim slips into the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you? You've been here  before, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What gave you that idea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know, maybe because our  lives depend on it, I just sort of  thought you knew what you were doing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get all agitated on me. I bought  a bottle of rum from a couple of  dudes, I heard 'em talking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get this straight. We drove  all the way down to Klan country  'cause you heard a couple of guys  talking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you complaining about? It  worked out. Everything's cool. Now,  come on, let's head down there and  see what's shaking. We deserve a  little reward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dubious) Reward?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are people down there having  fun. I want to be one of them. I  want you to be one of them. On Monday  you can be a bank teller if you want,  but tonight you're a bootlegger with  a truck full of Puerto Rican rum and  a fistful of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A look of excitement crosses Claude's face, but he quickl shakes it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's gas money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exasperated, Ray stuffs a few bills into Claude's pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's your gas money. You stay  here and watch the truck. And don't  worry, I've got the keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Left alone, Claude mutters and kicks at the dirt. He lean against the truck.

dialogues.speaker: UP AHEAD/EXT. JUKE JOINT
dialogues.text: Ray emerges from the woods and heads down the hill toward the juke joint. Claude hustles up next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just gonna keep an eye on you,  make sure you don't do nothing stupid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ramshackle den of iniquity on the banks of the Mississi The band is laying down some serious Delta blues, creatin an inviting atmosphere for sin and moral corruption. On a far side of the room, Ray is playing poker with some LOCALS. He seems to be having a bad night. WINSTON HANCOC a formidable black man, sweeps in another big pot and puf happily on his cigar.

dialogues.speaker: OVER AT THE BAR
dialogues.text: Perched on a stool, Claude shoots a dark look at Ray and  motions for the door. Ray waves him off and returns to hi game. Claude becomes aware of a soft, young female hand o his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen you in here before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring at the hand) That's because I've never been here  before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Sylvia. What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Against his better judgement, Claude's gaze follows the l slender arm up past a bare shoulder and settles on SYLVIA angelic face. He is struck dumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you remember your own name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it begins with a "C"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. "C", how about buying a  girl a drink? (to the bartender) Two bourbons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really shouldn't. I gotta keep an  eye on my friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks like he can take care of  himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The drinks arrive. She places a shot glass in Claude's  reluctant hand. She winks provocatively and slowly pours whiskey down her throat. Instinctively, Claude tosses bac his shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude. That's my name. Claude. That's  never happened before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're cute. You have any money,  Claude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten dollars. But I need it to get  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would you want to go home? It's  so early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender refills their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT THE POKER TABLE
dialogues.text: Winston considers his cards, hardly looking up as a WAITR lays down a cocktail napkin and sets a drink down on top it. He glances at Ray, who casually considers his cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take two.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dealer tosses Ray a couple of cards. INSERT -- Ray fans his cards to reveal a full house. After considering the other players at the table, Ray pus what's left of his money into the center of the table. Th three other PLAYERS fold with disgust. Winston squints lo and hard at Ray, then pushes everything he has into the c of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston reaches into his jacket and throws down some more money on the pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And while we're at it, let's sweeten  the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like my sugar bowl's empty,  Mr. Hancock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching for the pot) That's just too damn bad, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, hang on, slick. I ain't through  with you yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray checks his cards again. He looks at the pot, it's a l of money. With this hand, there's no way he can lose. He  places his daddy's pocket watch on top of the pile. Winst checks the time piece.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll cover it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray lays down his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full boat, ladies doing the paddling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four threes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray sits back, stunned. Winston rakes in his winnings. Th game is over for the night. The three other players head the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take it too hard, New York.  Have a round on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston tosses a silver dollar to Ray, who snatches it ou of the air. Winston drops his hat on his head and moves  through the crowd and out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get you something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray shakes his head. Carefully, she begins to clear the t Suddenly, he grabs her wrist. Winston's glass tips over. flips over the cocktail napkin to reveal an extra pile of cards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like he had a whole lot of  nothing in his hand until you came  along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wrenching free) You're hurting my arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray dashes into the street, glancing both ways. No sign o Winston. Damn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston produces Ray's pocket watch and pops it open. A s crosses his face as the mechanical tune plays. A sheriff's sedan rounds a corner, illuminating Winston i its headlights. The car pulls up and SHERIFF WARREN PIKE  steps out. Distinguished by a casual cruelness, he's a yo white man who loves his uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it isn't Winston Hancock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston tries to move past Pike, but the sheriff blocks h path with a night stick. As Winston backs off, another sq car pulls up behind him. TWO DEPUTIES step from the car,  guns drawn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we agreed that you were  gonna leave town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to leave, Sheriff Pike. But  your wife begged me to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pike slams Winston with his club, sending the black man t his knees. As Winston struggles back to his feet, a stile flashes and he lunges for the sheriff, slashing his cheek The deputies grab Winston from behind, holding him by bot arms. The long knife clatters to ground. Pike touches his face, examining the blood on his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just committed suicide, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray walks slowly down the hallway to Room 13. He is about knock when he hears the sound of lovemaking from within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray opens the door and peeks in. Sylvia's on top and in  charge. Claude is concentrating real hard. Ray smiles to  himself and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude hitches up his suspenders as he comes down the sta He finds Ray having a drink at the now-empty bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray. I've been looking for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess we better get going, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still got that ten dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not exactly. See, I met this  girl. Real nice girl. God-fearing  girl. Her name's Sylvia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That jelly you were talking to right  here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in a tight spot. Her mama needs  this operation, and they ain't got  the money for it. Their church took  up a collection but they were still  short...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you made a generous contribution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I say? When the spirit moves  me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was mighty charitable of you,  Claude. Looks like we both got fucked  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While you were upstairs doing God's  work, I was getting jack-legged by a  fool with four threes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost all our money in a card  game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He even got my daddy's watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck that cheap-ass watch -- (off Ray's glare) I mean, how the hell are we gonna  get home without any money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've still got 36 cases of rum.  That's better than money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude head down the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure the truck's this way? (looking over his  shoulder) I swear it was back that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the bloodied figure of Winston Hancock lurches  from the shadows and grabs Claude by the lapels. Claude i too scared to scream, staggering backward. But the man's  grip loosens and he slips to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (croaking) Ray... Yo, Ray...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns back to find Claude trembling with fear and cov in blood. He just points down. Ray eyes widen. He kneels  down and turns Winston's body over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he's hurt pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, man, I've never seen a dead body  before!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much to Claude's horror, Ray starts rifling through Winst pockets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think you're doing?! The  man's been dead for two seconds!  Don't you have any respect?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ain't there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daddy's watch. This is the dude I  was telling you about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the glare of two bright headlights from a picku truck freeze Ray and Claude in a guilty tableau. FIVE WHI MEN appear at the end of the alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gingerly releases Winston's lifeless body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong with that one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him? He's just drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, nobody puts 'em away like old  what's-his-name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Winston. His name's Winston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Ray, better get Winston  back to the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude and Ray hoist Winston's body to its feet. The man  raises his lantern, takes a closer look at Winston's face

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fella looks dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude check for themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you look at that, Ray. Winston  up and died on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell with him then. If he can't share  the driving, he can't ride in the  truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He can ride with us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, the men all have guns. And they're pointed at R and Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So can you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a holding cell, Ray tests the window bars. Solid.  Meanwhile, Claude sits on a cot brooding darkly. Through bars, we see the rednecks laughing and passing around a b of bootleg rum with the DEPUTY on duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, this is gonna delay everything.  Spanky's gonna be pissed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spanky's gonna be pissed? Poor Spanky.  Fuck Spanky! What the hell kind of a  name is Spanky, anyway? You're  responsible for this situation. I  blame you for everything. If it wasn't  for you, I'd be home having a hot  meal right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it wasn't for me, you'd be washing  up on the beach at Coney Island right  now. (mocking Claude) "I need all my thumbs and fingers  for praying and doing good."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jailhouse door opens and Sheriff Pike walks in. He pa to give the prisoners the once-over. There's a fresh band over the cut on his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we have here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Billy Bob and the boys found them  down down under the hill with Winston  Hancock. He was dead. Looks like  murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like they was running rum. Got  thirty six cases of evidence out  back. You want I should call in the  federal prosecutor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's not drag the feds into this. I  can think of better uses for that  rum than letting it collect dust in  some government warehouse up in  Nashville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pike winks at his deputy, then turns to regard the prison

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, why bother with bootlegging  when we got us a clear cut case of  murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, sheriff. As we explained  to your associate here, there's been  a mistake. We didn't kill anybody.  Now, as for the bootlegging, we happen  to work for a very important man in  New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Does the name Spanky  Johnson mean anything to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnson is very well connected.  If you were to let us go, I guarantee  he would show you his appreciation,  if you know what I mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you offering me a bribe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just trying to pay the toll on  the road to justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may be able to buy your way out  of trouble up in New York City, but  down here we take murder seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, man, how many times we gotta  tell you people, we didn't kill that  guy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if that's the case, then you  don't have anything to worry about,  do you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pike turns his back on the prisoners and checks the time a gold pocket watch -- Ray's pocket watch. But from his c Ray can't hear the mechanical tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time to get home to the missus. See  y'all in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the cell, Claude turns to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man's gotta point. We're innocent,  after all. I just gotta get a good  night's sleep on this filthy mattress.  Keep our heads on straight, stay  cool, what's the worst thing that  could happen to us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA Scorseses in on the JUDGE'S face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gavel comes down with a thundering crash. Stunned, Ra and Claude resist the BAILIFFS' efforts to remove them fr the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life?! How long is life? We were  just walking back to the truck. We  didn't do nothing! Fuck life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life?! What's life mean? There's no  way I can do life. I got a job starts  Monday morning!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue to protest loudly as they are dragged bodil through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blues music kicks in as a prison transport bus rolls down dirt road cutting through the bleak Mississippi Delta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG-CHAIN CHARLIE, a white prison sergeant, sits behind wheel. A shot gun hangs within easy reach. The CAMERA MOVES BACK past grim-faced PRISONERS with thei hands and feet shackled. We arrive at Ray and Claude sitt in grim silence as the bus lurches along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus veers off the country road and passes under a sig MISSISSIPPI STATE PENITENTIARY. Sgt. Dillard's voice PLAY OVER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to the farm. Here you will  be provided with ample opportunity  to repay your debt to society through  the rigors of hard labor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude stare out the window, getting their first  look at the harsh reality that awaits them. Cotton fields stretch to the horizon in every direction. HOE-GANGS till the earth under the watchful gaze of TRUSTY SHOOTERS...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In between harvest and planting season  we got fields need clearing, roads  need building and ditches need  digging. You will eat only what you  can grow. Your crop don't come in,  you'll go hungry. If you die, don't  worry 'bout us none. We'll find  somebody to replace you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Along the road, CONVICTS cast hard looks at the new men a the cart passes. A WHITE SERGEANT on horseback shifts his rifle and casually spits tobacco juice in the dirt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A low-slung, single-story bunkhouse surrounded by a dirt  yard. Two shooter shacks sit at diagonal corners of the y In each shack, two trusties with rifles keep vigilant wat over the camp. SGT. FRED DILLARD paces down the line of n men as HOPPIN' BOB, an uncommonly ugly trusty, unlocks th leg irons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This here is Camp 8. Camp 8 is for  incorrigibles, so whatever you've  done to get here, believe me, we're  not impressed. You new men are  probably noticing that we have no  fences here at Camp 8. We don't need  no fences, we have the gun line. It  runs from shack to shack clear around  the yard. You are now inside the gun  line. If you step outside the gun  line without my permission, you will  be shot. If you trip and fall over  the gun line, you will be shot. If  you spit, if you pee, if you stick  your ass out and take a dump over  the gun line, you will be shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard plucks a hat off one of the new prisoners and tos it over the gun line. SHOTS ring out from the nearest sha The hat is torn to shreds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of my trusties puts a bullet in  you when you're trying to run, I'm  liable to give him a pardon for saving  me the trouble of tracking you down,  so you can bet their aim is true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard puts a cigarette in his mouth. Hoppin' Bob is rig there with the flame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Sgt. Dillard. In the  unlikely event that you need to  address me, you call me boss. You  already met this handsome fella right  here. Hoppin' Bob's my ace boon coon.  You run afoul of Hoppin' Bob, you  run afoul of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nodding to Bob, Dillard saunters off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New men, strip down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude share a look. Self-consciously, the men be to undress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Double bunks line the walls, with a footlocker for each  inmate. As usual, there's a poker game going on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, ladies, got some fresh meat  for ya!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All activity comes to a halt as the new men shuffle into cage wearing their prison-issue "ring-arounds." Hoppin' B slams the metal doors shut behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ain't got no wallflowers at Camp  8. Everybody gotta dance eventually.  But don't worry, they won't try  nothing tonight. That would take all  of the fun outta the courtship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The INCORRIGIBLES hungrily eye the new men in total silen Claude sticks close to Ray as they shuffle toward their  assigned bunks. The CAMERA SETTLES on a much younger WILL LONG.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inmates jump down from the mule cart and grab hoes an shovels. Because he can't count, Hoppin' Bob keeps track the men using a system all his own -- a PEBBLE in his poc for each man. Dillard stands by with his shotgun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got three miles of ditch to clear  today. Let's keep it moving!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men of Camp 8 labor under the brutal mid-day sun. JAN LEG, a handsome, muscular man, sings a verse to set the w tempo. Up and down the line, a mighty chorus responds. Th CAMERA FINDS Ray and Claude swinging pick axes, sweating  profusely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't believe this before Abe jive.  I didn't go to night school to sing  in no Mississippi Boys Choir!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude stops to catch his breath and take off his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't do that if I was you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. It's too damn hot. What do  you know, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SHOT rings out. Claude hits the ground as a bullet kick up some dust nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude looks up to see Dillard cracking pistachio nuts as Hoppin' Bob puts another round in the chamber of his rifl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why ain't his pick swinging?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (echoing) Why ain't that pick swinging?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too hot, boss. I'm tired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says it's too hot, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too hot, huh? Well, you tell that  lazy jiggaboo the state of Mississippi  ain't interested in his meteorological  assessments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen up, jiggaboo! State of  Mississippi ain't interested in  your... in your... (off Dillard's look) metropolitan assets!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him the state of Mississippi is  only interested in getting this ditch  cleared by sundown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State of Mississippi wants this ditch  cleared by sundown. You got that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got it... boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He don't sound like he's from 'round  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's from New York City. That one,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York. That's up north, ain't it?  They'll find we do things different  down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annoyed, Dillard jabs the butt of his rifle into Ray's so plexus. Ray sinks to his knees in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like we got a couple of live  ones. How long these boys in for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge gave 'em the long ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life, huh? They step outta line again,  we'll shorten up that sentence real  fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard swaggers off, dogged at the heels by the ever fai Hoppin' Bob. Resigned, Ray and Claude return to their lab

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men rest in the ditch as BISCUIT, a slight inmate wit red bandanna tied around his head, dispenses water, one l per man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drink it up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie exchanges two cigarettes for a second ladle. POKER FACE pulls a crumpled envelope from his shirt. His expres never changes, hence the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Either of you new fellas know how to  read? I've had this letter four months  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't read? None of these guys  can read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last fella who could read made parole  'round Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even know who this is from.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, gimme that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray unfolds the letter and scans it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's from your mama's neighbor, Mrs.  Tidwell. She thought you oughta know  that your second cousin Bo died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoners express their condolences. "Sorry, man." "T some bad news." "I know you loved Bo like a brother..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your other cousin, Sally, on  your daddy's side, she died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More sympathy from the men. "Ooh. Twice in one letter." " break, Poker Face..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apparently, your sister died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jenny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it says Marleen here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Relief all around. "Thank goodness."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, wait, looks like Jenny died,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Bad luck, man." "That's harsh..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then it goes on for a while about  how the crop didn't come in on  accounta the frost. (flips over the page) She finishes up with something about  a tornado and how your mama and your  daddy died in that. But don't worry  none. She'll take care of the dog.  That is, if it gets over the worms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoners share dark looks. Ray folds up the letter a hands it back to Poker Face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody else need anything read?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "No, man, we're good." The men shake their heads and retu letters and cards to their pockets. Jangle Leg nods and  switches places with one of the convicts, parking next to Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever done time before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You kidding? I've been in and out of  prison my entire life. Mostly in.  I'm hard-core.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you won't have no problem making  the adjustment. You need anything,  help of any kind, gimme a holler.  Name's Jangle Leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Preciate it. Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they shake, Jangle Leg inspects Claude's hand thorough

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft and supple. Like a lady's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes narrowing) I try to moisturize regularly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over his shoulder) Hey, Jangle Leg, what'd I tell you  about pitching woo on the job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Cap'n.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude snatches back his hand and gives Jangle Leg a hard look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Break's over! Back to work!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the men grab their tools and return to work, Claude le over to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you think they call him Jangle  Leg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody just told me he wins the  three-legged race every year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does it all by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wincing with each movement and covered in grime from the  day's labors, the new men bring up the back of the chow l COOKIE, the grub-slinger, slaps a large dollop of an  unidentifiable substance onto Ray's tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Creamed chip beef on toast. Except  we're outta beef, so I had to  improvise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't I get one of those steaks you  got grilling back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are for trusties, unless you  got thirty cents or two packs of  cigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another prisoner lays down some tobacco and gets a juicy  steak. Ray grabs a hunk of corn bread and makes his way t the back of the room. Claude steps up, holds out his tray for Cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I don't like it when the  food touches each other, so if you  could just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- keep everything separate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disappointed, Claude turns to discover that the only seat left is next to Ray. Scowling, he limps toward it. Jangle Leg's eyes follow Claude as he approaches the tabl Biscuit smacks him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eyes front, mister!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude sits down and promptly goes to work scraping his b toast with his knife. The irritating sound slowly brings entire room to dead silence. All eyes fall on Claude. Scr scratch, scratch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stepping up) Problem with the toast?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie glowers and takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop aggravating people. Just eat  your food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the room returns to normal, Claude starts polishing hi fork with his shirttail. Irritated, Ray shoots him a look

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This fork is filthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fork is the least of your worries,  Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Undeterred, Claude breathes on his fork and polishes it s more. Disgusted, Ray pushes aside his plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me? Willie Long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you in for, Willie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a long story...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he was 13 years old he killed a  son-of-a-bitch with a claw hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They never proved that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a second, you've been in here  since you were thirteen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you, Radio?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armed robbery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn liar. Bitch killed his sister  with an axe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was my half-sister. Shit, I ain't  the son-of-a-bitch who poisoned my  own parents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protective) They deserved it. Very strict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you, Biscuit? You nearly  skinned your poor old landlady alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least he didn't kill Santa Claus  with his bare hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You killed Santa Claus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scolding) On Christmas Eve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wasn't the Santa Claus, he was  just wearing the suit and ringing a  bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you guys do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole table waits expectantly for their reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I kinda lost track of how many people  we killed that night. Must have been  15 or twenty -- not counting women  and children. It was a real bloodbath.  All that screaming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pack of lies. Don't listen to him.  We didn't kill nobody. We were  railroaded. And we gonna prove that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just blocked it out. Nigger's  crazy. He's the one who did all the  stabbing. He's capable of some heinous  shit. (thumbing down the  table) How 'bout him down there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the table, GOLDMOUTH, a hulking specimen, s menacingly, flashing a glittering set of teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goldmouth? They say he was born out  back behind the shithouse. That's  what they say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all been here a long time. Doesn't  anybody ever escape from this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They run but they never get too far.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple years back, Cookie made it  clear to Greenville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greenville, that the nearest town?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) It's a two-day walk if you don't get  lost. Take a mighty cagey country  boy to navigate the woods and bayous  between here and there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those dogs they got can sniff a skid  mark in your underpants from a half- mile off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, well, let's say you make it  to Greenville. What's there, anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandma Dodi's Pork Rib Joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where they nabbed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't even get to have my peach  cobbler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most important thing they got in  Greenville is a train that heads up  north.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, Goldmouth stands up, casting a shadow over Cla

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, girl, you gonna eat your corn  bread?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude looks up, considering his options.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, man. I want you to have it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait up there, Claude. You give that  guy your corn bread and the next  thing you know you'll be ironing his  shirts and clipping his toenails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I oughta eat your corn bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My corn bread? Oh no, my friend. I  love corn bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray picks up his corn bread and takes a huge bite out of rolling his eyes with enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought my mama made good corn  bread but this is really something  special.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks at the faces around the room, smiles broadly.  Goldmouth is getting embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who knew I'd have to come all the  way down to this here prison, deep  in the asshole of the great state of  Mississippi, to find such a tasty  piece of corn bread?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoners begin to laugh. Ray's got them now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who knew that in this great corn  bread-making institution I'd come  face to face with the biggest,  ugliest, stinkiest, ugliest gold- mouthed negro in the entire world.  Now get out of my face before I lose  my appetite!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A punch sends Ray sprawling in the dust. Goldmouth looms  over him. The incorrigibles form a circle around the  combatants. Poker Face, the camp bookie, is taking all be

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you like your corn bread now,  New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goldmouth and Ray square off. Goldmouth swings, Ray ducks and counters with a swift jab to the gut. Goldmouth just  flashes a shiny grin and clobbers Ray with a fist the siz of a Thanksgiving turkey. Ray sinks to the dust. Radio dr down near him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, New York, you can do better  than that! Get up and show him how  they do it in Harlem!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray shakes his head and staggers back to his feet. He cir the big man and gets in a couple of good shots, much to t crowd's approval. Goldmouth shakes his head and wipes the blood from his nose. Now he's mad. He grabs Ray by the sh and delivers a crushing blow. Ray reels backward into Coo arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate you going to all this  trouble over my corn bread. I don't  get a lot of compliments in my line  of work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie shoves Ray back into the ring for more punishment. Claude emerges from the mess hall, munching on a piece of corn bread. He squeezes in between Poker Face and Willie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your pal's getting the tar whipped  out of him on your account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many times I got to tell you? He  ain't my pal. Besides, he looks like  he knows what he's doing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then Claude winces as Goldmouth delivers a jaw-crush uppercut that knocks Ray on his back. Claude bristles und the incriminating looks coming at him from all directions

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, alright...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude crouches down as Ray rolls over on his stomach and pushes himself up onto all fours. His eyes are swollen sh his face covered with blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray, I think you made your point,  whatever that is. Maybe now's a good  time to throw in the towel. You know  what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray manages a smile and staggers to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slurring) Shit, Goldmouth. Back in New York, I  know bitches who hit harder than  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goldmouth pulls back his fist and lets it fly. Ray hurtle through the crowd, collapsing in the dust. Willie steps i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man's taken enough of a beating.  Let's get him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie, Radio and Poker Face raise Ray to his feet. Goldm slings him over his shoulder and carries him toward the  bunkhouse. Dazed, Ray catches Claude's eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got him good, huh, Claude? He won't  be bothering us anytime soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A quick elbow jab from Goldmouth and Ray is out for good. Disgusted with himself, Claude tosses what's left of the  corn bread to the mangy dog, who makes short work of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wagging a finger) Shame, shame, that's your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On Sundays, the mess hall also serves as a chapel. From a makeshift pulpit, the blind REVEREND CLAY and his DAUGHTE lead the congregation of convicts in a rousing chorus of  "Down by the Riverside."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gospel music filters into the yard, where the prisone mingle with kinfolk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. DILLARD hums along with the gospel music as she plac a couple of freshly-baked pies on the window sill to cool

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA FINDS Claude and Daisy walking hand in hand to a simple shack just beyond the gun line. This is the TONK HOUSE and Dillard is the gate keeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Request permission to go to the tonk,  boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard considers Daisy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see no wedding ring, Banks.  Conjugal visits are for married  prisoners only.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you could make an exception  just this once, boss? She came all  the way down from New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need the Baptists on my back,  but I suppose I could issue a  temporary marriage license for a  nominal fee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy gets the picture. She reaches into her purse and ha Dillard a couple of dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I now pronounce you man and wife. (calling to the shooter  shack) Claude Banks going to the tonk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude takes Daisy's hand and leads her over the gun line

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE YARD
dialogues.text: Ray watches Claude and Daisy step into the tonk house. Th he returns to a game of horseshoes, tossing a ringer. Nea Biscuit gives Jangle Leg a haircut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biscuit, when you're done with Jangle  Leg, you think you could squeeze me  in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thought you'd never ask. Biscuit  needs some gravy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about a haircut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cost you a pair of nylons.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray, Goldmouth don't believe  me. Ain't it so they got trains up  in New York City that run under the  streets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're called subways. A nickel  will take you from one end of  Manhattan to the other. Helluva ride,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radio looks up from a vacuum tube receiver he's busy  repairing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray, you ever been to the Cotton  Club?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I've been to the Cotton Club.  It's pretty sweet. But it don't hold  a candle to the Boom Boom Room. That's  where the real action is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the Boom Boom Room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my joint. The swinginest  nightclub in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got your own nightclub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not yet. It's still in the  planning stages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it don't exist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just because it's in my mind,  Goldmouth, don't mean it ain't real.  Everything worth anything starts  with a dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoppin' Bob calls to Ray from the gun line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gibson! Got yourself a visitor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns to find his MOTHER, a handsome woman in a flora dress, coming toward him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayford!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The incorrigibles elbow each other and repeat the name  "Rayford" as Mama Gibson envelops her son in a fleshy emb smothering him with kisses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, mama?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard some things so I went to see  Spanky Johnson. He told me what  happened and gave me some money to  get down here. What happened to your  face?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about that. Hey, fellas,  this here is my mama. These are some  of my friends. That's Willie, there's  Poker Face, Radio, Cookie, Goldmouth,  Biscuit, Jangle Leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The motley crew gathers around, nodding politely. Goldmou flashes a golden grin. Willie gallantly doffs his cap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Gibson. Shame on Rayford here  for failing to mention that he had  such a beautiful mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mama manages a half-hearted smile, clutching her bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to meet you all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was your train ride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
