dialogues.text: Quite comfortable, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Them cookies in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, oatmeal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse me, you got any batteries on  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biscuit sides up, fingering her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a lovely dress. Make it  yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely unsettled) Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and his mama sit in the shade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a big surprise, mama. I sure  didn't expect to see you down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, uncomfortable beat. Mama's lip starts to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rayford, I wanted so much more for  you than this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cry, mama. This place ain't so  bad as it looks. Sure, we work hard,  but there's plenty fresh air and  sunshine... And you know something  else, I've taken to going to church  regular. They got services every  Sunday right there in the mess hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you lie to me, Rayford. (composing herself) You still have your daddy's watch? (Ray shakes his head) Well, this is all I can give you. I  wish it was more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts some money in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't take that, mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't argue with me. You need it  more than I do. I know how a little  money can help in a place like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly, Ray stashes the money in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe this. I always said  I'd never end up like this. I thought  I'd make something of myself, do  something with my life. You know, be  successful. Have a big house, a  family. Now I'm gonna end up just  like daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't say that, Rayford. Don't ever  say that. He gave up hope. That's  where you gotta be different.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gave me life, mama.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave you life. And they can't take  it away from you. Remember that.  You'll get outta here someday. I  believe that. You gotta believe it,  too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reclining on a straw mattress, Claude watches intently as Daisy gets dressed. The rickety door reverberates with a  loud pounding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Time's up, Banks! We got a crowd  gathering out here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude leaps from the bed and slams his fist against the  door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woman came all the way from New York,  goddamnit! We'll come out when we're  good and ready!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy quickly buttons up her dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you go see my cousin Maynard  like I asked you in my letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I did. He said he'd file  an appeal right away. You didn't  tell me he was so good looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, that side of the family has  all the looks and none of the brains.  I hope he don't mess things up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He seemed like a pretty good lawyer  to me. His offices take up an entire  floor of that big, new building on  125th Street, and he was using all  these words I never heard before. He  even offered me a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A job, huh? Well, that's nice, real  nice. You won't have to work long.  I'll be back soon enough. After I  start work at First Federal Bank of  Manhattan, I'll be keeping you in  style. Everything will get back to  normal again. That's a promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daisy smiles weakly and looks away. She doesn't have much faith in this promise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Claude, Maynard wanted to  know if he should file the appeal on  behalf of your friend, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Gibson? (thinks about it) No, no. He's the reason I'm in here,  Daisy. For all I know, he's got a  record a mile long. I got a better  shot of getting out of here on my  own. You tell Maynard to think about  me, concentrate on me. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Claude, whatever you say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoners jump down from the cart and grab hammers an pick axes as Hoppin' Bob keeps count with pebbles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We lost yesterday on accounta the  rain. That means we gotta make up  for it today, so put your backs to  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard the boss! Let's move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude jump down after Willie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (squinting at the sun) Looks like a scorcher.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet the son of a bitch goes over a  hundred and ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take that action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long line levels a road to a work tune being sung by  Jangle Leg. Dillard checks the thermometer on the truck -- 90 degrees and rising. Mopping his brow, he starts down the line. The sun arcs overhead, a blazing inferno... Heat rises of the road... The men sweat profusely... "Taking it off her boss!" echoes up and down the line. Biscuit has his work cut out for him, lugging a water buc from man to man, offering the ladle. The sun... the hammer... the ladle... the axe... the sun. the hammer... the ladle... the axe... The mercury hits 11 degrees... A NEW GUY lets his hammer slip from his fingers, collapse in the dirt. Radio nods to Poker Face, who hands him a pa of cigs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man down, boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard uses his foot to roll the stricken man over. He's still alive. Barely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two, put him on the truck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude drop their tools, grab the man by his arms and legs and lug him up to the road. Once out of earshot, Ray whispers to Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie drew me a map to Greenville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'm saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know what your saying. And  I'm saying if you made it that far,  they'd be watching every train that  pulls out of that station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why we won't take the train.  Cookie showed me where there's a  farm house. They got a boat there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about boats? I bet  you can't even swim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the truck. With effort, they swing the man bac and forth and launch him into the back of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I know about boats is they take  you to freedom. Come on, man. I think  we can do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you always talking about we?  There is no we. There is a me, there  is a you. But there is no we between  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude continue their conversation as they lather for a shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want out of this place, don't  you? Don't tell me you're starting  to like it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't like it here. Look around.  There's nothing but ass. Male ass!  Balls and ass! Believe you me, I'm  getting out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna forget it. What does  that mean? If you've got a plan, I  think I have a right to know about  it. I told you my plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting a map from a chubby chef  named Cookie? Dragging our asses  through the swamps in search of some  worm-eaten boat? That ain't a plan,  that's a vacation for two in the  hole. When you've got a map to New  York City, you get back to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude splits. Scowling, Ray finishes up his shave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Moonlight streams through the barred windows of the cage. Exhausted from the day's work, each man stretches out  painfully in his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure was hot out there today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still too hot to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every bone in my body feel like a  big son-of-a-bitch dog got hold of  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait 'til Sunday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so great about Sunday? Monday's  right after it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Restless, Radio rolls over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray, what's the name of that  nightclub of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean the Boom-Boom Room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. The Boom-Boom Room. Sure  would like to see that place when  you get it up and running.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have come by last night,  Radio. You woulda had yourself some  fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night? What are you talking  about, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talking about old Satchmo nearly  blew the roof off the joint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satchmo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Louis Armstrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a good friend of mine. Drops by  the club whenever he's in town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, do we have to listen to this  bullshit? I'm trying to get some  sleep around here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Shut up, Claude!" echoes around the room. Irritated, Cla thumps his pillow and turns his back on the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, things were hot last night,  but you'll never guess who's playing  tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BLAM! A high horn note sounds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE-UP -- Biscuit, all dolled up and flashing a million dollar smile. She begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tisket a tasket...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biscuit is up on a makeshift platform in the bunkhouse,  lipsyncing to Ella Fitzgerald. But its not the depressing bunkhouse anymore, it has transformed into Ray's Boom-Boo Room. PULL OUT SLOWLY as Ray, decked out in a sleek tuxed steps in front of the CAMERA. He speaks into the CAMERA a he walks...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, fellas. Catch any cab  heading uptown. All the drivers know  Ray's Boom-Boom Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks to his left, sees Goldmouth in the old bunkhous

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I at, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in nightclub) C'mon, Goldmouth, somebody's gotta  watch the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PANS off Ray to Goldmouth, in a tuxedo, at the front door of the nightclub with two lovely ladies. He wa to himself, sitting on his bunk. Himself waves back, smil like a kid in a candy store. Willie is behind the bar, serving drinks to three gorgeou SKIMMIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray, I could get used to this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON Cookie sitting a table eating a huge porterhouse The CAMERA DOLLIES around to find Ray eating with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, my man, this steak is like  butter!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Made just for you, Cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about some steak sauce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem. Oh, boy!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray motions to a busboy clearing a table. It's Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about some Worchestershire sauce!  And clean that damn table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude grimaces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie laughing, Goldmouth laughing, Poker Face in the bu laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray, I know you got some  gambling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray at a craps table holding a pair of dice. He looks at  Poker Face on his bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, Poker Face, what's a club  without some dice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK as Ray throws the dice. A perfect s The CAMERA PANS UP to Poker Face in a tux clutching a fis of cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucky seven! My nigger! Let it ride!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the room, Jangle Leg, in a tux, sits at the piano. Radio, also in a tux, beats on the drums.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sing, girlfriend!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biscuit sings the song, smiling lovingly at her man. Ever is having a great time in Ray's Boom-Boom Room, until... Whistles blow. At the front door, Hoppin' Bob appears wit FIVE TRUSTIES dressed in police outfits. The incorrigible scatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray, looks like trouble!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hard white light from Hoppin' Bob's flashlight shines  directly into the CAMERA. CLOSE ON Ray, in his bed, back in the old bunkhouse. The  music stops abruptly. He shields his eyes from the harsh  light. Hoppin' Bob is looming over him. It's back to real

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't shut up, you're gonna spend  the rest of the night in the hole,  Gibson! That goes for the rest of  you girls, too. I don't want to hear  another peep about no Boom-Boom  fucking Room!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A loud burst of flatulence cuts through the darkness. Hop Bob turns his flashlight on Cookie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Cap'n.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scowling, Hoppin' Bob steps out of the cage and locks the door behind him. The men slowly settle back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Pretty good story, Ray. Didn't much  care for the ending though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lights out at Camp 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude's playing pepper with Radio, Jangle Leg and Poker  Face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mail call!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The incorrigibles quickly gather around as he calls off n passing cards and letters through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Craddock!... Williams... Henshaw!...  Banks!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard hands the letter to Ray, who glances at it before passing it back to Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) Maynard Banks, Esquire. Attorney at  law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme that. That doesn't concern  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude rips open the letter. A profound disappointment se over him as he reads the news from cousin Maynard. Bitter he crumples up the letter and tosses it down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard strolls down the line with his rifle over his  shoulder. Under his watchful gaze, hoes rise and fall. Af he passes, Claude moves a little closer to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cool) Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure is hot today. Think it'll rain  later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want, Claude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I want? What makes you think  I want something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daddy always said when a man starts  talking about the weather keep you  hand on your wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daddy must have been a helluva  guy, a deep man, a wise man. Sure  wish I could have met him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut the bullshit. What do you want,  Claude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearing his throat) You still got that map?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you're still thinking about  booking it, I want in. I think we  can make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We? Did I hear you say we? As I  recall, you're the one who said there  is no we. Guess we got some bad news  in that letter, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, my cousin Maynard is a lawyer.  He filed an appeal on my behalf --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On your behalf. What happened to we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The appeal was denied. Then Daisy  went and fell for Maynard. They're  engaged to be married, can you believe  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's just think about that  for a moment. He's a successful lawyer  up in New York City and you're down  here with a bright future in the  cotton picking business. Eeny, meeny,  miney, Maynard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man. Don't shut me out. I'm  telling you, you and me, that map,  we can go places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what, Claude? This whole  time we've been down here, you've  done nothing but think about yourself,  acting like this whole thing is my  fault. That plan with your cousin,  did that include me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you're honest for once. So  now you want to be my friend? Well,  let me tell you something, Claude-my- shit-don't-stink-Banks. You got a  lot to learn about friendship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean I'm in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so, Claude. You'd just  slow me down. We'd have to stop every  five minutes so you could polish  your silverware. There's no way around  it, you're soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said you're soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me that. You know I hate  it when you call me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gets in Claude's face and silently mouths the word -- "soft." Claude throws down his hoe and sinks his fist dee into Ray's gut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, that felt good. I should have  done that the first time I met you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray touches the blood coming from his nose. Eyes blazing, tackles Claude, dragging him to the ground. The two men r around, trying to strangle each other. Hoppin' Bob hustles down the hill and drags Ray off of Cl But Claude comes back for more. Hoppin' Bob finds himself the middle of the fray. That's when the cavalry arrives. Two trusties use their r to crack Ray and Claude over the backs of their heads, se them both down for the count. Hoppin' Bob empties his canteen over their faces. They sp back to consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you girls set aside your  differences and get back to work or  I'll see to it --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- we'll spend a night in the hole.  We heard this shit before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude stagger to their feet and pick up their to Hoppin' Bob and the trusties head back up the hill. Ray s to chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are you laughing about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray opens his palm to reveal TWO PEBBLES. Claude regards with new-found respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One by one, the prisoners of Camp 8 climb into the mule c under the watchful eye of Hoppin' Bob. As each man passes he removes a pebble from his pocket. The last one in is  Willie. Hoppin' Bob's pocket is now empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All in, boss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Movin' it out, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard spurs his horse, escorting the mule carts back to camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the carts fade into the distance, Ray and Claude pop u from a roadside ditch and take off for a grove of trees i the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running for all they're worth, Ray and Claude crash throu the bramble. Claude trips over a root and sprawls face fi in the bushes. Ray turns around and helps him to his feet Claude is still laughing giddily. He throws his arms arou Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did it, man! You got us out!  Next stop, New York City!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York's a long way's off. Let's  just keep moving, okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ray and Claude disappear into the woods...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radio's pulling in some jazz music out of New Orleans.  Prisoners hit their bunks as the floorwalker does the nig head count. He stops at Claude and Ray's empty bunks, gla around, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard smokes a cigarette on the swing. His wife steps o with a fresh bourbon and ice. Suddenly, SIRENS start to w and emergency floodlights blaze to life at Camp 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hounds scramble down from the back of a truck and gather  around the DOG BOY. He holds out a handful of soiled laun and a dozen snouts sniff it thoroughly. Nearby, Dillard gathers a DOZEN MEN with rifles and  flashlights into a posse. He puts a cigarette in his mout Hoppin' Bob lights it for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trees rise ominously around Ray and Claude as they push  through dense underbrush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know these trees all look the same,  but I'm getting an awful familiar  vibration from this one right here.  You sure you know where we're going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely. The map is very clear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take a look at that map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude considers it from various angles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call this a map? What was Cookie  smoking when he drew this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie didn't draw it. I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You drew this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you wouldn't come if I didn't  have a map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That gripes my soul, man. We're out  here in the middle of nowhere. There  is shit nibbling at my balls! Don't  tell me you don't know where we're  going!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray shrugs and presses on. Dumbfounded, Claude considers map again, then tears it to shreds. The braying of hounds echoes through the trees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wait up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude race through the underbrush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard and his men follow the dogs through the woods, ho on the scent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude race up to a chain-link fence. On the othe side, an old Ford is parked on a dirt road. Hearing the p closing in behind them, Ray and Claude fling themselves o the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The posse is gaining ground. Dillard takes two men off to the left, sending the rest of the men straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude clears the fence first and scrambles for the old F Ray's shirt snags on a piece of wire as he drops down fro the fence. Stuck, he dangles helplessly a few feet off th ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude yanks open the door and jumps behind the wheel. TW WHITE TEENAGERS bolt up in the backseat where they were  necking. After a beat -- group scream. The half-dressed  teenagers dive from the car and scramble off down the roa Claude twists the key in the ignition and the engine roar to life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Ray, time to go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm stuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude sees Ray caught up on the fence, then hears the so of the approaching posse. If he floored it right now, he  might make it. But he can't just leave Ray hanging there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude runs up and grabs Ray's legs, pulling for all he's worth. The shirt rips free, sending Ray and Claude tumbli to the ground. They leap to their feet and turn toward th car -- running smack into the barrel of Dillard's shotgun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD BLACK PRISONER delivers a frosty mint julep to  SUPERINTENDENT ABERNATHY who rocks slowly in his chair. A his feet, his 10-year-old daughter MAE ROSE is playing ja Her long blonde hair makes her look like a little angel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, daddy. They caught those two  men who escaped last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mae Rose is pointing down the drive, where Dillard and a  couple of trusties march Ray and Claude toward the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't men, Mae Rose. They're  convicts. And nigger convicts to  boot. Can you say nigger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nagger?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nigger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's my girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bound by leg irons and handcuffs, Ray and Claude are depo at the bottom of the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here they are, Superintendent. We  tracked 'em all the way to the  Tallahachie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's quite a ways. I'm glad you  New York boys could see some of our  lovely countryside while you're down  here. What do you say, Mae Rose? How  should we teach these two a lesson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mae Rose considers their faces. Ray and Claude look like  they've been to hell and back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A night in the hole?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better make it a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard nods and turns Ray and Claude around. As they mar back down the drive, Abernathy takes sip of his mint jule and affectionately pats Mae Rose on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The incorrigibles of Camp 8 gather at the gun line, watch silently as Dillard and a couple of trusties march Ray an Claude toward the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trusties shove them each into a small, dank cell and  slam the doors behind them. Dillard secures both doors wi an iron bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you in a week, boys.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray slumps to the floor, propping his feet against the wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Claude. I just want to say thanks  for coming back for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude considers his bleak surroundings. It's a small,  uncomfortable space, not even big enough to lie down. Jus tin bucket for a toilet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't mention it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Hell, you'd probably be half way to  New York by now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious, man. Don't mention it.  Ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun beats down on the tin roofs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoners are gathered around a table, laying out mon As usual, Poker Face is keeping tabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take Claude to die on Wednesday  for fifty cents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wednesday for two bits. And don't  forget you already owe me a steak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll take Claude for Friday. That's  my birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With an ear to his receiver, Radio slaps his money on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weatherman says a heat wave's coming.  I say neither one of 'em son of  bitches gonna last past Thursday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you before, I don't take  pennies. Two cigarettes or one nickel  minimum. What about you, Willie?  Gonna get in on this action?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a crispy new dollar bill says  both of them gonna make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This gives the men pause. Willie tosses his money on the  table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's what I call a bet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a mighty long shot, Willie.  Nobody ever made it a week in the  hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in August, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Willie leaves the money where it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who else has some guts around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poker Face makes notations as the betting resumes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Work goes on as usual for the prisoners of Camp 8. Trusti keep their eyes peeled for slackers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The brick shacks bake in the noonday sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Biscuit moves down the line offering the ladle to the men they struggle under a crushing heat wave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superintendent Abernathy strides up and gives the nod to  Dillard, who unlocks the doors. Huddled in their respecti cells, Ray and Claude shrink from the bright sunlight. Th slowly and painfully, they rise to their feet. In the background, the incorrigibles gather at the gun li as word spreads that the fellows are still alive. Abernat glances at the crowd with annoyance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think these boys have learned  their lesson. Let's give 'em another  week for good measure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you want to do that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you ever question me, Sgt.  Dillard. When I give an order, you  jump to it, or I'll kick you and  that first-cousin you call a wife  outta that pretty little house so  fast it'll make your pin-head spin.  You got that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard slams the doors on Ray and Claude and clamps shut the padlocks. Abernathy smiles at the incorrigibles, who  regard him with undisguised hatred.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE GUN LINE
dialogues.text: A somber Poker Face offers Willie a wad of bills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, they made it a week. Looks  like you win, Willie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A slot at the bottom of the door opens. A tin plate of mu slides through and the slot closes. Slumped in the corner Claude reaches for the food -- but a RAT beats him to it, scampering out of the shadows and leaping onto the dish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A commotion and wild screams come from Claude's cell. Ray leaps to his feet, shouting through the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude? You alright?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude continues to stomp the rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't take it no more, Ray! Die,  motherfucker! Gotta get the fuck  outta here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude pounds against the door, raising a holy racket. We continue to cut back and forth between cells as needed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep it together, Claude. You wake  up the man, he'll shoot you for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd be doing me a favor. I'm getting  outta here one way or the other!  Goddamn rats and shit! Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude continues shouting and pounding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, man, just settle down.  We'll get outta here, Claude. We'll  get outta here real soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the fuck are we gonna do that,  Ray?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks around his cell. Claude's pounding is bound to  wake up somebody soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just get off at the next stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stops pounding,  confused) Say what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, we'll get off at the  next stop. The train's pulling into  the station right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hell you talking about? What  train?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the Bronx, my man. Hundred  and Sixty First Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude focuses on what Ray is saying and starts to breath easier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hundred and Sixty First Street? That's  Yankee Stadium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, yes, Yankee Stadium. Bombers  are playing a double-header against  the Red Sox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red Sox... Who's on the mound?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Who do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Allie Reynolds. He's my boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, it says Allie Reynolds right  here in the program. He's warming up  right now. Man, we're so close to  the field I need cleats. How'd you  get such good seats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They must be the right people. Whoa,  there goes the hot dog man. Let's  get a couple. Damn, that smells good.  Nothing like a ballpark hot dog,  huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get ketchup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ketchup? Who eats ketchup on a hot  dog? Mustard's what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't eat it with mustard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard strides toward the hole, shotgun in hand. He paus to listen to the argument, cocking an eyebrow in befuddle

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Give me back that hot dog. I'll eat  it myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) What am I gonna eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) You can starve to death for all I  care. Now shut up, the game's about  to start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Hey, man, is Babe Ruth in the lineup  today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Of course, he's in the lineup. There  he goes right there. Hey, Babe...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard shakes his head, shoulders his gun and heads back toward his house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abernathy gives the nod to Dillard, who unlocks the doors Two trusties drag Ray and Claude out of their cells.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men crowd around the windows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on? Are they alive or  dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look too good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're not moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly, Claude opens his eyes, squinting in the harsh lig of day. Summoning his strength, he staggers to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Ray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's eyes blink open. Claude holds out a hand and helps stand up. They share a look. They made it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scowling) Sergeant Dillard, make sure these  two are out in the fields first thing  in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abernathy turns on his heels. Dillard considers the two t guys standing before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, get inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude stagger toward the bunkhouse as the  incorrigibles gather on the porch and help them in out of the sun.

dialogues.speaker: TIME PASSAGE
dialogues.text: (Note: This montage is mixed with 16mm and Super 8 footag A beautiful 1940s song plays over.) A. King Kong is machined-gunned off the top of the Empire State Building... B. FDR introduces his New Deal... C. The incorrigibles chop weeds... D. With Willie and Claude standing guard, Ray samples a b of moonshine from a secret still in his footlocker... E. At the height of the depression, poor people line up i front of a soup kitchen... F. Ray and the crew sit around the poker table playing ca and laughing... G. Ray opens a letter and pulls out a snapshot of his mam which he places over his bunk. H. The incorribles level a road... I. Jesse Owens wins the 100 meter race at the 1936 Olympi in Berlin... J. Benny Goodman sets the kids dancing with wild abandon the aisles of the Paramount Theater... K. The Hindenburg bursts into flames... L. Claude writes a letter, "Dear Sylvia"... M. In the juke joint, Sylvia reads the letter and smiles. She shows it to a few other WORKING GIRLS... N. Adolf Hitler stabs the air in front of a foreboding se of Nazis... O. The 1939 World's Fair opens in New York... P. Ray nails a sign to the side of the bunkhouse: RAY'S B BOOM ROOM. He steps back to admire the effect. Behind him Sylvia and her friends mingle with the incorrigibles in t yard... Dillard takes his cut as Claude and Sylvia head f the tonk house. Ray and his date step up... Q. Lou Gehrig is honored at Yankee Stadium. "Today I cons myself the luckiest man on the face of the Earth..." R. With a pillow stuffed under a home-made Santa outfit, distributes chocolate to the incorrigibles while Claude a Willie decorate the saddest little Christmas tree you eve saw. S. The 1940 Oldsmobile is introduced... T. Japanese Zeros bomb Pearl Harbor... U. FDR declares "a day that will live in infamy."... V. A WWII newsreel shows American G.I. s storming a beach the South Pacific...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inmates of Camp 8 cheer for the American soldiers up a makeshift movie screen. Instead of black and white stri the prisoners now wear blue twill. In an audience of new  faces, the CAMERA FINDS some familiar ones. Ray and Claud are surrounded by their crew -- Willie, Radio, Poker Face Cookie, Biscuit, Jangle Leg and Goldmouth. A decade has  passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of NEW PRISONERS stands before Dillard, now 10 yea older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Camp 8 is for incorrigibles, so  whatever you've done to get here,  believe me, we are not impressed.  You new men are probably noticing  that we have no fences here at Camp  8. We don't need no fences, we have  the gun line. It runs from shack to  shack clear around the yard --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard pauses in front of a big country boy who can't be more than 18 years old. The kid is bouncing a rubber ball

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell you think you're doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The kid don't answer. An OLD GUY steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, boss. That kid don't talk.  Something wrong with his head, just  can't get right, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't get right, huh? We'll see how  long he last. Now, where was I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't need no fences at Camp 8,  boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. We don't need no fences,  we have the gun line. It runs from  shack to shack clear around the yard.  You are now inside the gun line...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and some of the fellas are playing poker. Dillard's v drifts in through the open window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mouthing along) If you step outside the gun line  without my permission, you will be  shot. If you trip and fall over the  gun line, you will be shot. If you  spit, if you pee, if you stick your  ass out and take a dump over the gun  line, you will be shot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He lays down his cards and rakes in the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jangle Leg pitches to Radio, who swings and misses. Behin the plate, Goldmouth tosses the ball back to Jangle Leg. the sideline, Ray teaches three-card monte to CAN'T GET R Claude paces nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try to teach 'em the finer points  of the game, share my wisdom, but I  don't know why I bother. They don't  listen, they sure don't learn...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another pitch, another strike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you're dealing with here is a  complete lack of talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of watching Camp 12 win the  championship. Every year they get to  roast the victory pig and we get  dick. This year I want that pig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Radio knocks a grounder up the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Radio, there you go. Who  wants to hit next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right looks at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to hit? (to Claude) Yo, Claude. Give Can't Get Right a  shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical) Him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't be worse than any of these  other fools.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, grab the bat. Let's see  what you can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right shuffles to the plate. Goldmouth hands hi the bat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jangle Leg's gonna throw the ball  nice and easy. You just go ahead and  take a swing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jangle Leg tosses the ball. Can't Get Right swings and  connects with a mighty CRACK! The incorrigibles crane the necks as the ball disappears into the sky. They turn to l at Can't Get Right. Ray gives Claude a significant look,  then tosses another ball out to Jangle Leg on the mound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's try that again. This  time give it a little juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jangle Leg nods, winds up and delivers a whistling fast b Can't Get Right clobbers it. Once again, the incorrigible track the departing projectile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Told ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right smiles for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men of Camp 8 paint a fence along the drive leading u to the big house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard Camp 12 got themselves a son- of-a-bitch used to pitch for the Mud  Hens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That boy got a year for jay-walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge must have money riding on the  championship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't matter who Camp 12 puts on the  mound. All I know is when this  season's over Camp 8's gonna have  pork chops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then a U. S. Army Jeep swerves past the men and park in front of the mansion. Young CAPT. TOM BURNETTE helps M ROSE out of the car. The prisoners stare furtively at her long legs and curly blonde tresses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like little Mae Rose has grown  up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm-mm, that girl's got gams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got it all. And it's firm and  round and fully packed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shred it, wheat. That there is  fresh water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to them, Can't Get Right stares openly, mesmerized b her beauty. Ray nudges him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be cool, man. You can look, just  don't drool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up at the mansion, Abernathy and his WIFE come out onto t porch, all smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was the honeymoon? Am I gonna be  a grandaddy soon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't pay attention to the  superintendent, Tom. You're going to  stay for supper, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afraid not. I'm shipping out this  afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prisoners steal glances as Mae Rose kisses her new hu goodbye. She gives them quite a show, raising her leg beh her just like Betty Grable. Then Tom climbs into the Jeep and pulls away. Mae Rose takes a long glance at the prisoners. The men al look away -- except Can't Get Right who stands there smil innocently. Mae Rose gives him a little wink, then turns back and bounces up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A plump PIG roots about in a small pen. A sign dangles fr a post -- "First Prize." The incorrigibles of Camp 8 limb up for the big game with the inmates of Camp 12 across th field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think you can handle something that  big, Cookie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I handled your mama, didn't I? Don't  y'all worry. I got plans for that  bad boy. Ain't none of him going to  waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beyond the fence, a late-model sedan rolls up. STAN BLOCK in a straw hat and a rumpled suit, climbs out and stretch his legs. Irritated, he smacks a mosquito and exchanges a few words with Dillard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banks! Get over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude hustles over, removing his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Stan Blocker. Scout for the  Nigger Leagues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negro Leagues, actually. Pittsburgh  Crawfords. Ever hear of us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get the games on the radio  sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We played down in Jackson yesterday.  Heard a rumor you've got a boy up  here who can hit the ball a ton.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You probably mean Can't Get Right.  That's him over there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right? That's the kid's  name? Can I talk to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can try, but you won't get too  far. Why you interested?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawford's are always looking for  new talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you didn't notice, but this is  a prison.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are ways around that. Right  sergeant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blocker winks at Dillard, then glances at the incorrigibl practicing in the field. Goldmouth, Cookie, Poker Face,  Biscuit -- they don't exactly inspire confidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice looking squad. See you after  the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blocker takes a seat on the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The inmates of Camp 12 are in the field. Our boys from Ca 8 cheer for Cookie digging in at the plate. Ray taunts th opposition from the third base line. The PITCHER winds up and releases a fast ball. Cookie swi and connects for a base hit up the middle.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE STANDS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Abernathy and Mrs. Dillard share a box of Cracker Ja

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, the superintendent's hoping  for a boy, but personally, I'd prefer  a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever it is will be a little gift  from heaven. Look at the way she  glows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mae Rose sits next to them. She is SIX MONTHS PREGNANT. S removes her sunglasses and coyly bites a fingernail when spots Can't Get Right in the on-deck circle.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN ON THE FIELD
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right smiles shyly. Sensing trouble, Claude ush Can't Get Right toward the plate, massaging his shoulders

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my boy, just keep what little  mind you have focused on the game.  If you hit that ball the way I know  you can, you might just be our ticket  off this farm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right digs in. Claude returns to the sidelines appeals to the gods. The pitcher winds up and releases a  fast ball. Can't Get Right connects with that familiar CR Blocker stands up and watches the ball clear the fence an just keep going. With his team cheering him on, Can't Get Right trots arou the bases. But he's still looking at Mae Rose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cookie slowly turns the pig on a spit over an open fire. incorrigibles are savoring a victory feast. As always, tr guards keep an eye on things. Off to the side, Blocker is laughing with Ray and Claude. takes a hit off Ray's bottle of shine. It's not his first either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark my words, within five years  there's gonna be a colored man playing  in the majors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, the world hasn't changed  that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not yet. But it will. And I'll  be out of a job. Damn, that's some  tasty hooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's amazing what Ray here can do  with a couple of pounds of potato  skins and some molasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Blocker, what do you think of  our boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that boy could be the next  Josh Gibson. I'm gonna talk to the  front office about him, you can bet  on that. Damn, it's getting late. We  got a game in Memphis tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blocker starts for his car, parked just beyond the gun li

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about us? Don't forget to mention  us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're like his handlers. He can't  function without us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll put in a good word for you.  You've done a good job with that  boy. Thanks for your hospitality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude's eyes gleam with hope as Blocker's car ru off down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, a woman screams in agony. Then, the HEALTHY CRIES a new-born baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superintendent Abernathy paces anxiously in front of a wh curtain surrounding Mae Rose's bed. Suddenly, Mrs Abernat staggers out from behind the curtain with a stricken look her face. She tries to speak, but words fail her. Her leg go wobbly and she faints dead away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, doctor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DOCTOR steps from behind the curtain, drawing it behi him. He checks Mrs. Abernathy's pulse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be fine. She just had a bit  of a shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Mae Rose okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's doing just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the baby?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vague) He's a big one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a boy! Well, let's get a look  at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abernathy pushes past the doctor and yanks open the curta Mae Rose is propped up in bed, looking exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, where is he? Where's my new  grandson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The NURSE turns around, cradling the baby in her arms.  Abernathy gently pulls back the soft blanket. His eyes wi with horror upon discovering that the newest member of th Abernathy family is black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right bounces his rubber ball off the wall, cat it on the rebound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray passes around his latest batch of buck as the men dis Can't Get Right's professional prospects. The thump-thump the ball on the wall outside plays over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think they'll let him out  of here just to play baseball?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Boy's got God-given talent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God may have given it, but Claude  Banks spotted it and nurtured it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn straight. I expect those  Pittsburgh Crawdads to remember that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawfords.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing out the  window) Heads up, here comes trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abernathy drives his sedan up to the bunkhouse. All of hi worldly possessions are strapped to the roof. It appears  that the Abernathys are leaving town. In the back seat, M Rose cradles her baby. Her mother sits next to her. Dilla steps out into the yard to confer with the Superintendent then turns to address the inmates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, listen up! I want every man  lined up out here in the yard on the  double! Let's move it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard what the man said! Move  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abernathy holds his newborn grandson up next to Ray's fac Hmm. Scowling, he moves a little further down the line,  scrutinizing the features of each man. He pauses in front Claude, holds up the baby. Maybe. Abernathy stops in fron Goldmouth. Holds up the baby. The possibility makes him  shudder. He moves on to Can't Get Right. His eyes narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it was somebody from this  camp. I can feel it in my bones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgusted, Abernathy hands the baby back to Mae Rose. The he turns, walks back to Can't Get Right and places a revo against his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who the father of that  little chocolated baby is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right nods slowly. Abernathy smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then, who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up and down the line, the men brace themselves for the wo Can't Get Right just grins. Enraged, Abernathy cocks the  revolver. That's when Ray steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The baby's mine, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stunned, Abernathy lowers the gun and approaches Ray. The Claude steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's lying, boss. I'm the father of  that baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confused, Abernathy looks back and forth between the two  men. Then Willie steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, it was me, boss. I know I  may look old...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any fool could see that baby's mine,  boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg to differ. That cute little  rascal belongs to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the father, boss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the father...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so it goes down the line, until every last man of Cam has stepped forward to claim kinship with the Superintend Even hard-ass Dillard can't help cracking a smile. Disgus confused and thoroughly fed up, Abernathy jams the revolv into his belt and climbs into the car. As he guns the eng Mae Rose gazes out the back window, smiling one last time the father of her baby. Can't Get Right smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's visiting Sunday and Ray's Boom Boom Room is in full  swing. Sylvia's girls are everywhere. Down at the gunline Dillard takes his cut from inmates lined up for their tur in the tonk. A FIVE-PIECE PRISON BAND is playing the blue Nearby, Willie is dispensing Ray's moonshine from a bunkh window. He raises a jar in a toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To Superintendent Abernathy. May he  have many more grandchildren!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The incorrigibles erupt in boisterous agreement. Claude g Can't Get Right and shakes him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I want to know is where? When?  How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasting your breath, Claude. He ain't  the type to kiss and tell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just then, Rev. Clay and his daughter emerge from the mes hall and start across the yard. It's a good thing the old man is blind because he wouldn't want to see how far his  flock has strayed. The Reverend inhales deeply as one of  Sylvia's girls passes nearby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a sweet fragrance in the air  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The magnolias are blooming early  this year, daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blissed out incorrigibles enjoy a last dance as the band  downshifts into a slow, sultry number. In the midst of th dancers, Claude clings to Sylvia. Nearby, Jangle Leg danc intimately with a YOUNG WOMAN. Up on the porch, Ray refreshes Biscuit's drink. Biscuit h been crying and it shows. The liquor probably isn't helpi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take it so hard, Biscuit. She  don't mean nothin' to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell with him. It ain't that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pulls some folded sheets of paper from his pocket, pas them to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are free papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (devastated) What am I gonna do out there, Ray? I  can't go home to my mama like this.  I'll get the strap for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Biscuit, this is good news.  Your mama's gonna break down in tears  when you show up on her doorstep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Poker Face leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) I'll give you three to one she gives  him the strap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gives Poker face a shove, then turns back to Biscuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's 1945. It's a different world  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for me, it ain't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well you can't stay here, Biscuit.  This ain't no life for a man. Any  one of these fellas would give their  right arm to be in your shoes. I  sure know I would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray hands back the papers and heads off to dance with a P YOUNG WOMAN lingering nearby. Left alone, Biscuit polishe off his moonshine and checks his reflection in the bunkho window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No life on the inside, no life on  the outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He crumples the discharge papers and drops them. Then he  steps down from the porch and walks calmly past the danci prisoners toward the gun line. Ray lifts his head off his date's shoulder. Something abo the way Biscuit is walking suggests that he isn't going t stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Biscuit...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's too late. Biscuit crosses the gun line and keeps walking, his eyes focused on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man over the line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The band stops playing, the dancers grow still. Dillard t around and squints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamnit, Biscuit, get back here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Biscuit isn't paying attention. He breaks into a run. Dillard nods to Hoppin' Bob who raises his rifle and draw bead. But he can't pull the trigger. He lowers his gun. Shots ring out from the shooter shacks. Biscuit reels fro the impact of the bullets and looks down sadly at the blo spreading across his ring-arounds... Prisoners silently gather at the gunline. Jangle Leg push his way through the crowd and crosses the gunline without hesitation. Dillard indicates for the shooters to hold th fire. They train their rifles on Jangle Leg as he strides toward his fallen companion. Jangle Leg gently lifts Bisc lifeless body into his big arms and somberly carries him  back toward the camp. The CAMERA RISES HIGH OVERHEAD as t prisoners make way for Jangle Leg to cross back over the  gunline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark mood hangs over the men. Jangle Leg sits stoically Radio fiddles with his receiver. Nearby, Poker Face and R play a listless game of gin rummy. Claude is thumbing  distractedly through a dog-eared copy of Baseball Digest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, fellas, I got Chicago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But nobody can muster much enthusiasm for this news. Radi shrugs and drops down on his bunk. Just then, Can't Get Right walks past heading for the doo He's dressed in civilian clothes, his bindle slung over h shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Can't Get Right, where you going?  Why you dressed like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right holds out a piece of paper which Ray  scrutinizes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a pardon from the governor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The incorrigibles gather around for a glimpse at Can't Ge Right's ticket to freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right nods out the window. Stan Blocker is wait by his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude storms across the yard and stops at the gun line. is a few steps behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yo, Blocker, what's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid's getting out. I got him a pardon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but what about me and Ray? I  didn't see our names on that pardon.  You said you were gonna put in a  good word for us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did, Claude. I mentioned you. I  mentioned you both. But the fact is,  pardons don't come cheap. The kid  can hit. What can you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This hits Claude hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let it go, Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not gonna let it go. The man  needs to explain himself. Makin'  promises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I am truly sorry about this.  I'd like to help you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least the kid's getting out. Isn't  this what you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude looks around as the incorrigibles begin to gather. He's on the spot. Dillard approaches with Can't Get Right Claude looks into the big kid's eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (resigned) Yeah. Of course it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steeling himself to the reality of the situation, Claude  gives Can't Get Right a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You show them Crawfords how to play  ball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make 'em throw strikes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right nods. He steps up to the gun line and loo at both shooter shacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright. You're a free man now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't Get Right steps across the gun line. Blocker opens car door for him. But before he climbs in, Can't Get Righ reaches into his pocket and pulls out his rubber ball. Wi a smile, he tosses it to Claude, who snatches it out of t air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, we'll take good care of  him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blocker tips his hat and climbs behind the wheel. Claude Ray watch Blocker's car drive off under a red Mississippi sunset. Slowly, the inmates drift back toward the bunkhou until Ray an Claude are left alone at the gun line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the new kids said they're  farming those acres just north of  the swamp. He said he saw a crop  duster flying around the place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not in the mood right now, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said they keep it parked out behind  the barn. Can't be that hard to fly  a plane. Lots of people do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're called pilots! I'm serious,  Ray. I'm not in the mood for one of  your stupid, fucked-up plans right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see you coming up with any  plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting mad) My plan is on his way to Pittsburgh  right now. That congenital idiot  just got himself a pardon signed by  the governor thanks to us, but we  can't seem to do nothing for  ourselves. Don't you feel a little  disgusted right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crop duster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't getting in no airplane with  you. I'm finally wrapping my mind  around the concept. They threw us in  this shithole for life. Don't you  get it, Ray? We're gonna die here!  Might as well head up to the cemetery,  pick a plot and start digging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly enraged, Ray hauls off and knocks Claude down wi a solid right. Surprised, Claude touches his bloody lip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daddy died in prison. He gave up  hope and hung himself. What you're  talking about is the same damn thing.  That ain't how I'm going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're fooling yourself, Ray.  Maybe you're just a chip off the old  block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take that back or we ain't friends  no more, Claude Banks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's a news flash, Ray. We never  were friends. We've just been stuck  together for 12 years. It's been  nothing but bad luck since the moment  I ran into you. Every time I look at  you I get sick to my stomach thinking  about what my life could have been  if I'd never bumped into Ray Gibson.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hard look comes to Ray's eyes as Claude rises to his fe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better watch yourself Claude, before  you say something you regret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only thing I regret is the day I  met you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if that's the way it is...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I have nothing left to say to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray walks away, leaving Claude to nurse his split lip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never said nothing of value  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: TIME PASSAGE
dialogues.text: A. In his Pittsburgh Crawfords uniform, Can't Get Right l into a fast ball, sending it soaring into the bleachers.. B. People dance in the street in Time Square, marking the end of WWII... C. Hoppin' Bob drops a package on Ray's bunk. Ray rips of the brown paper to reveal a book: "So You Want to Learn t Fly..." D. Claude and Sylvia make love in the tonk house... E. In the mess hall, Ray pointedly carries his tray past table where Claude sits with Willie... F. An A-bomb explodes in the Bikini Atolls... G. Jimmy Stewart hugs his wife and children at the end of "It's a Wonderful Life"... H. Jackie Robinson slides across home plate at Ebbets Fie I. Ray runs full tilt across a field toward a barn. Sure  enough, there's the single engine crop duster parked righ where he said it would be... J. Claude and another INMATE repair a hole in the bunkhou roof. They dive for cover as Ray's crop duster swoops low overhead and dips out of sight beyond the trees. A puff o smoke rises into the sky... K. Soot-stained, Ray is marched to the hole and shoved  inside... L. Newly elected president Harry Truman holds up a copy o the Chicago Tribune baring the headline "Dewey Defeats  Truman"... M. RCA unveils the first color television... N. Cars pull up next to speaker poles in front of a drive movie screen... O. In the bunkhouse, early rock and roll plays on a moder 1950s radio that sits where the old vacuum tube receiver  used to be. A YOUNG TOUGH now occupies Radio's old bunk.. P. At the poker table, Poker Face slumps forward onto his pile of chips, revealing a straight flush. The other men  quickly fold... Q. With a TRUSTY standing guard, Claude and Ray silently  shovel dirt into Poker Face's grave. The CAMERA MOVES pas gravemarkers -- Biscuit, Jangle Leg, Radio... R. Marilyn Monroe's skirt rises on a blast of subway air "The Seven-Year Itch"... S. Rosa Parks is arrested for refusing to sit in the back the bus... T. Elvis Presley creates a sensation on the Ed Sullivan  Show... U. School children learn to "duck and cover" in the event nuclear attack... V. The inmates of Camp 8 work to level a road. Ray's on o side, Claude's on the other... W. Prisoners mingle with friends and family on visiting  Sunday. Claude waits on the bunkhouse steps. His face  brightens when Sylvia appears... X. Blacks sit-in at lunch counters in Greensboro, N.C... Y. Kennedy is elected... Z. OMITTED... AA. Martin Luther King delivers his "I have a dream" spee at the Lincoln Memorial... BB. The Zapruder footage of Kennedy being shot... CC. American soldiers jump down from helicopters and run the jungles in Vietnam... DD. Ford introduces the 1965 Mustang... EE. The assassination of Malcolm X... FF. Muhammad Ali looms over Sonny Liston, asking "What's name?"... GG. The CAMERA MOVES past more gravemarkers -- Hoppin' Bo Goldmouth -- to find Claude and Ray silently shoveling di over another casket. Ray pounds a simple marker into the  ground: Cookie. Briefly, they lock eyes. But neither one  speaks and the moment passes... HH. Go-Go dancers... II. Mao Tse Tung... JJ. Jimi Hendrix at the Monterey Pop Festival... KK. TV's Batman and Robin battle the forces of evil in Go City... LL. Black Panthers... MM. Peace Protesters... NN. The death of Martin Luther King... OO. Robert Kennedy... PP. Neil Armstrong sets foot on the moon... QQ. Vida Blue rears back and fires a pitch in the 1972 Wo Series...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the porch, Willie, now in his 70s, sits in a wheelchai watching the ball game on a black-and-white television. A TRUSTY waits nearby. Ray, now in his mid-60s, emerges fro the bunkhouse lugging a duffle bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright Willie, I think I got  everything. I'll talk to Dillard,  see if I can get up to the infirmary  and check up on you. Make sure they're  changing your diapers regular.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll be sending you up there soon  enough. And not just for a visit,  neither.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning in) I slipped in a couple of bottles of  my latest batch. Help wash down all  them pills they'll be giving you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gives Willie a slap on the back and nods to the trusty The trusty wheels the old man across the yard where YOUNG PRISONERS mingle with WIVES and FAMILY MEMBERS sporting t fashions of the early '70s -- Afros, mutton chops, paisle prints and bell-bottom pants.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE YARD
dialogues.text: Looking old-style, Claude sits on the mess hall steps wai for Sylvia. He catches Willie's eye. The two men nod to e other, an unspoken farewell. Then Claude turns to find Ra looking at him from the bunkhouse steps. Ray and Claude h each others gaze for a moment. Then Ray heads back into t bunkhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off) Are you Claude Banks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude turns to face YVETTE, a pretty young woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Yvette. Sylvia sent me.  You look just like she said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's alright, isn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, she's fine. She's just not coming  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She got married last month.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real nice guy, too. Trumpet player.  They moved down to New Orleans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude takes this in, staring off into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She always said that if you were on  the outside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm not on the outside. I'm in  here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she's sorry she won't be seeing  you anymore. Anyway, she wanted me  to take care of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, go to the tonk or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm too old for you. Besides, I'm  not much in the mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to come back some other time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Nice girl like you don't belong in a  place like this. But if you talk to  Sylvia, tell her old Claude said  congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude stands at the gun line, staring across at the Dill house. Mrs. Dillard places a couple of pies on the window to cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whites-only pies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly, he makes a break for the Dillard house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man over the line!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns to see Claude dashing across no-man's land. Sho ring out from the shooter shack, kicking up dirt around  Claude's feet as he serpentines across the field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathless, Claude makes it to the kitchen window and dig his hand into the golden-brown crust, shoving a sloppy fi of pie into his mouth. More shots ring out. Bullets PING around him. Grabbing the pie, he darts around the side of the building, out of range. Back against the wall, he dro down on his haunches, snarfing pie like a hungry wolf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A case of empty Coke bottles sits in the middle of the ya glinting in the hot sun. His face smeared with boysenberr Claude finishes taking off his boots and socks and steps  barefoot onto the bottles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comfortable?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a pair of fur-lined bedroom  slippers, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll see what those slippers feel  like after, say, 24 hours. And if  you step down off them bottles -- if  one toe so much as touches the dirt --  one of these boys is gonna shoot you  dead. Let's see. We need a special  man for this job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a trusty's rifle and moves among the inmates, wh have gathered around. He stops when he gets to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How about it, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray glances at Claude, then back at Dillard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make you trusty right now. If  that pie-eatin' son of a bitch falls  off those bottles and you have to  shoot him, I'll see to it you get a  pardon. Hell, I'll personally escort  you out the gate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dillard offers the rifle to Ray, who doesn't have to thin too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to give me a gun,  boss. I'm liable to use it on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's been given the same treatment as Claude. Barefoot,  balanced on Coke bottles, the two men stand a few feet ap facing each other. A trusty with a rifle keeps an eye on  them. After years of silence, the tension reaches the bre point...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a sucker. I'd have taken that  deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me? Are you talking to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have knocked you off those  bottles, put a bullet in your ass  and be half way to New York right  now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After all these years of blissful  silence, I almost forgot how annoying  the sound of your voice can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope you don't think I owe you  anything. Because I don't owe you a  damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
