dialogues.text: I didn't do if for you, anyway. I  just ain't no boot-licking trusty,  that's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trusty tightens his grip on his rifle. He'd love the  opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was sorry to hear about your mama  passing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but since we're talking, I  thought I'd mention it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not talking, you're talking,  and doing too damn much of it, if  you ask me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stand in stony silence. Then Ray starts to laugh. A  long, low belly laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure looked funny running for  those pies, bullets flying all around  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullets weren't the problem. That  pie was too hot. Burned my tongue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men start to laugh. Really laugh. Nearly a decade worth of laughter comes welling up out of them, and they  nearly lose their balance, which only makes them laugh ha

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A trusty bangs the rap iron. Young prisoners pour from th bunkhouse and line up for breakfast. Claude and Ray bring the rear, the elder statesmen of the bunch. By a long sho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fourteen acres today and only 12  hours of daylight! Eat up and move  it out! Gibson! Banks! Get your sorry  asses over here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude and Ray step out of line and approach Dillard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every morning I wake up praying that  Ray Gibson and Claude Banks have  died in their sleep and every morning  you disappoint me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stand before you a defeated man.  Try as I might, I can't seem to break  you. I swear, if they dropped a  nuclear bomb on this camp, you and  the cockroaches would be the only  things left. But starting today at  least I won't have to endure your  presence any longer. You've got  fifteen minutes to clear out your  footlockers. You're both being  reassigned to the Superintendent's  mansion. And I, for one, will not  miss you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude share a look. Then Ray embraces Dillard, w stoically endures the breach of his personal space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always wanted to do that. (sighing) There is so much love inside of this  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up on the porch, Claude brings a tray of minted iced tea Superintendent Wilkins, who sets aside his bible and wash down a couple of pills. Before going back inside, Claude can't resist taunting Ra busy trimming a hedge out in the hot sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yard boy, these pansies could  use some attention over here. Perhaps  some fertilizer would restore their  exuberance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude and Ray beat the bulrushes with switches, rustling couple of pheasants from their hiding spot. As the birds  take wing, Wilkins aims his shot gun and fires twice in r succession. Both birds fall from the sky in a flutter of  feathers.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude fills Wilkins' water glass as the Superintendent t a bite of lamb chop and winces in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn dentures slipping again.  Everything falls apart when you grow  old, eh, Claude? Time sure marches  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I'm fixing on retiring at  the end of the summer, gonna try to  enjoy what few years I have left.  What do you think of this place?  It's one of those new retirement  communities down on the Gulf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude glances at a glossy brochure. From outside, Ray pe suspiciously through the dining room window as he hacks a rose bush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ocean views, palm trees, two heated  swimming pools and a golf course --  sounds a damn sight better than that  infirmary across the way where I'm  gonna end up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude returns the brochure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize, Claude. That was rude  of me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's alright, boss. Takes a lot  more than a colorful brochure to  hurt my feelings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been on the farm for quite a  spell, haven't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over forty years now. Me and Ray  Gibson out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilkins glances over at the window. Ray ducks out of view

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty years. That's a long time for  any crime, even murder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a hell of a lot longer when  you're innocent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half the men in this prison swear  they're innocent. Don't you think  that's kinda funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have to forgive me if I don't  laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude pushes back into the kitchen, leaving Wilkins to t this one over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude are getting ready for bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and Wilkins sure are getting  chummy. You two planning on going  steady, or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's just a lonely old man. He likes  to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I'm a lonely old man. I like to  talk, too. So why don't we start by  talking about what kind of a plan  you're working on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not working on a plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't fool me, Claude. I know  you got something brewing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude punches his pillow and turns off the light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray hacks a rose bush down to the nub. From the garage co the sound of an engine turning over. Wilkins' 1973 Lincol Continental convertible lurches down the drive with Claud at the wheel. He screeches to a halt inches from Ray's le and climbs from the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch that car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude pulls out a hanky and buffs Ray's finger print off the hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilkins' driver's got the flu, so he  asked me to fill in for him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't driven in 40 years, you  ain't even got a license. Man's taking  his life in his hands, putting you  behind the wheel! Where you taking  him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greenville. We're picking up the new  Superintendent at the bus station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray scowls as Claude straightens his chauffeur uniform an heads up the path to the mansion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude pulls up in front of the station, steps out of the car and holds the door for Wilkins, who checks his watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I trust you, Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilkins heads into the station, leaving Claude alone with the Continental. All around him are the sights, sounds an smells of the free world. A woman rushes into the arms of man as he climbs off a bus. Across the street is Grandma  Dodi's Pork Rib Joint where Cookie never made it to the p cobbler. A young brother with a boom box walks by. In the street, kids crowd around the back of an ice cream truck. Then Claude catches his reflection in the car window and  frowns. When did he get this old? Unnerved, he moves arou to the back of the car and pops open the trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up) Damn, it was getting hot in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing in that  trunk?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't think I was gonna let you  escape alone, did you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't escaping! We're picking up  the new super just like I told you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're lucky I came along.  Doesn't take a visionary to spot a  golden opportunity like this. Now  help me out of this trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't getting out of that trunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, man, I'm starting to cramp  up here. (Ray struggles out of  the trunk) We have the chance right here, right  now, I say we go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go where, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back to New York for starters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what will we do when we get there?  I'm sixty-five years old, Ray. So  are you. What are we gonna do out  here? Get married, have kids, settle  down? That boat sailed without us,  man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This boat's gonna sail without you,  too. I don't care if I last one day  out here. At least it's one day of  freedom. Now gimme those keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about that. You run if you  want to, but you're not taking this  car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude, man, I'm serious. Give me  those keys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ain't spending a month in the hole  so you can take a joy ride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me take them away from  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, there's Wilkins!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks, Claude clocks him. Ray slumps back into the tr Claude stuffs Ray's legs back into the trunk and slams th lid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's driving now, bitch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up just as Wilkins and the new superintendent ex the bus station. Warren Pike's hair has gone grey and he' 40 years older, but there's no mistaking the former sheri of Natchez County. He still bears a nasty scar on his che from a wound inflicted long ago. CLAUDE'S POV -- Pike appears as a young man in his sherif uniform striding slowly toward him. Claude blinks and looks again. Pike has returned to his o self as he and Wilkins step up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dropping his bags) There you go, boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oblivious, Pike climbs into the back seat. Wilkins nods t Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Claude, time to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude snaps to it, grabbing the bags. He considers openi the trunk, but decides to carry them around to the front  seat with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Backs to the CAMERA, Ray and Claude urinate, presumably o the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure it was him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some faces you just don't forget.  Warren Pike's is one of 'em.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like it, I don't like it one  bit. We shoulda taken that car when  we had the opportunity. We'd be half  way to New York by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'd be in the hole by now. Hey,  man, you're peeing on my shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Simultaneously, they shake  and zip. Claude bends down and picks  up a bowl of gumbo, placing it on a  tray next to an identical one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilkins pours a frosty drink and offers it to Pike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemonade?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer bourbon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I don't keep any liquor  in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, fortunately, I carry my own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pike pulls a flask from his jacket and tilts it high. Cla enters from the kitchen with the two steaming bowls of gu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunting's been pretty good on the  farm the last few years. It's one of  the perks of the job. If you're  interested, tomorrow I could show  you some of my favorite spots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to twist my arm. (digging in) Say now, that gumbo has quite a kick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Claude. That'll be all  for tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Mr. Wilkins. Mr. Pike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pike nods coldly. Claude steps back into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't mind my saying, you  seem mighty familiar with your house  boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe in treating the convicts  with respect, if that's what you  mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic) Respect? Well, isn't that progressive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If somebody deserves respect, Mr.  Pike, they receive it from me, convict  or no convict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pike curls his lip with disdain before taking a healthy  spoonful of gumbo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude and Ray beat the bullrushes with switches. Amid a  flutter of wings, three pheasants take to the air. Wilkin fires first, knocking one out the sky. Pike pulls off two rounds, playing clean up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude dump their game bags into the back of a pi truck. Nearby, Pike drains his flask while Wilkins scrape mud off his boots. The breeze picks up, clouds fill the s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's a pretty good haul.  What do you say, Mr. Pike? Ready to  call it a day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pike pulls a gold watch from his pocket and releases the  face plate. A familiar mechanical tune floats on the gath breeze. Ray turns around slowly. His eyes fall on the wat in Pike's hand. His daddy's watch. In Pike's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's getting late. I could  sure use a bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a real nice watch you got  there, sir. Fancy old thing even  plays a little tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's special. They don't make  'em like this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure don't. Mind if I ask where you  got it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, my wife gave it to me on our  anniversary some years back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude looks at the watch, then at Ray. Uh oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must have been some time ago. Maybe  forty years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes narrowing) Something like that, yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She give you that scar, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pike thrusts the barrel of his gun up under Ray's chin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I oughta shoot you for that comment,  boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like you shot Winston Hancock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilkins turns to see Pike holding Ray at gunpoint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I'm gonna have to teach  this uppity nigger a lesson in  manners.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Mr. Uppity Nigger to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray grabs the barrel of the shotgun and slams it into Pik face. Pike rolls over and freezes, staring down the barre of his own gun now in Ray's hands. Confused, Wilkins poin his gun at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool it, Ray. You're gonna get us in  a lot of trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's right, Gibson. Put down the gun  and we'll work this out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna work this man's brains out  the back of his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shoot him, Wilkins!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't shoot, sir. I can deal with  this. (cautiously) Ray, buddy, you don't want to shoot  this white man. See, you do that,  they'll kill you for sure. And it's  not that I like you or anything, but  I've kinda gotten used to having you  around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got my daddy's watch, Claude. I  always knew whoever took that watch  killed Winston Hancock. And that was  you, Mr. Pike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's crazy. Don't listen to him,  Wilkins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize what your saying,  Gibson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That watch was the only thing my  daddy ever gave me. It meant the  world to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goddamn it, Wilkins, would you please  just shoot the nigger!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoots me, I swear I'll take you  with me! I just want to hear you say  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there any truth to what he's  saying, Pike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does it make? Natchez  was better off without Winston  Hancock! Who cares if a couple of no- account bootleggers went to jail for  his killing? At least the state of  Mississippi got 40 years of cheap  labor out of the deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forty years of cheap labor! Gimme  that gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude grabs for the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm gonna kill him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, believe me, I'm gonna kill him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude yanks the gun free and points it right in Pike's f Wilkins trains his gun on Claude. But the moment passes.  Claude lowers the gun. Bewildered, Wilkins does the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's because you're soft. Gimme  the gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said you're soft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't call me soft, I hate it when  you call me that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray mouths the word -- "soft." Claude clenches his jaw, p the gun and pulls the trigger. Click. Pike smirks and pulls a small gun from his boot. But as h raises it -- BLAM! Pike is hurled backward by a shotgun b Shocked, Ray and Claude look at Wilkins, his gun still sm in his hands. After a significant beat, Ray reaches down and gingerly  retrieves his daddy's gold pocket watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe this is mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A gurney carrying Pike's body is lifted into the back of van by two COUNTY CORONERS. Nearby, a distraught Wilkins  tells his story to a couple of SHERIFF'S DEPUTIES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I was drawing a bead on a bird  when Mr. Pike just stepped into my  line of fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were the two convicts when the  shot was fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were busy loading up the truck.  We got him back here as quick as  possible, but... I just feel terrible  about this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude watch through the window as Wilkins talks the deputies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't he just tell 'em the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows nobody wants to hear the  truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the deputies pats Wilkins sympathetically on the b Then he and his partner put away their notebooks and head for their vehicle. Wilkins heads up the steps and into th house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think they bought it. One of  the deputies belongs to my church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Visibly shaken, Wilkins takes a seat, wiping the sweat fr his brow with a handkerchief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize there's no way... There's  nothing I can say to make up for  forty years... I'll have Charlotte  prepare those pardon papers right  away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wilkins winces and swallows a couple of pills from his bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude, mind helping me to the  bathroom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (giving him a hand) Sure, boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not your boss. Not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake looks at Willie expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Ray and Claude got their pardons,  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smacking him) No, they didn't get their pardons,  you dumb shit! If they'd got their  pardons way back then, we wouldn't  be burying them today, would we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chewing on it) Oh, right. Well, why didn't they get  those pardons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old man Wilkins' never came out of  that bathroom. Died right there on  the crapper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like Elvis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course nobody believed Ray and  Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That musta messed 'em up pretty bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened to 'em after that,  Willie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that? Well, let's see. After  that they got old. We all got old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude, now in their nineties, sit under a tree i the courtyard listening to a Yankees game on a transistor radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Humphries was checking my  prostate this morning. I got an  erection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An erection, huh? Haven't had one of  those in a while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it. Scared me at first.  Then, before I could figure out what  to do with it, it was gone. Imagine  my disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the radio, the announcer voice rises in pitch as the  Yankees score. Ray and Claude share a satisfied look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure would like to see the house  that Ruth built one more time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Ruth shoulda built it a little  better. Damn thing's falling to  pieces. Gonna hurt somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you expect? It's almost as  old as we are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They oughta tear that shit down and  ship them Yankees cross the river to  Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember what that place looked like  on a sunny spring day? More beautiful  than any church I was ever in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TWO ORDERLIES push a DEAD BODY past on a squeaking gurney

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like old Jonesy finally got  his walking papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray tips his flask in a simple salute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over to the morgue and up the hill  to the cemetery. Never thought I'd  admit it, Claude, but you were right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course I was right. About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the one who said that  boneyard's the only way we're getting  out of here. We're gonna join all  the rest of 'em soon enough. Jangle  Leg, Biscuit, Goldmouth, Poker Face,  Cookie, Radio -- yes sir, pick a  plot and start digging...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray closes his eyes and settles in for a nap. Claude turn to watch Jonesy squeaking away. Something about what Ray  just said has given him an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oprah" blares on the television. Old convicts linger abo in various states of repose and decay. A young ORDERLY po to the music on his Walkman as he pushes a cart through t ward. Over at a table, Ray and Claude play poker with Willie, a SHAKY OLD JUNKIE and TWO YOUNG GANG BANGERS. The currency the table isn't poker chips, it's pills of various sizes colors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two Percodan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll raise you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck are those?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeps your cholesterol down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I look like I give a shit about my  cholesterol?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GANG BANGER #2 takes a quick hit of cocaine from a bullet He notices Ray staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a bump, G?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be putting that shit up  my nose. That came in in somebody's  ass. It's like you're sniffin' ass.  Maybe that's your thing, but it ain't  mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray pushes his bet to the center of the table. The shaky  junkie folds. Willie tosses in some pills and turns to Ga Banger #2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like it's up to you, stinky  ass sniffer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glaring, Gang Banger #2 flips a big pill into the pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thorazine? Well, that's a little  rich for my blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tosses down his cards. The shaky junkie attempts to li a cigarette. The match slips from his trembling fingers a falls into his lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn fool gonna set this place on  fire one of these days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gang Banger #1 folds. It's back to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got three stool softeners left. (to Gang Banger #2) That oughta be right up your alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The remaining players match the pot. Gang Banger #2 revea his cards. Willie frowns. Ray lays down his cards and  victoriously sweeps his winnings into a paper cup. Across the room, Nurse Humphries enters with a tray of snacks. S too, is showing the years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who wants Jell-O?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The magic word. The poker players join a stampede of olds in a clatter of canes, walkers and artificial limbs. Ray Claude are left alone at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, where you going? We got money  on the table here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude glances around to ensure that he's not overheard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, Ray, I've been chewing on  what you said this afternoon. I think  I got a plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gives Claude a long look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you trying to tell me after all  this time you finally have a plan  for busting out of here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh! Is that so hard to believe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me, I don't want to hear  it. It's probably all fucked up,  anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't want to hear it, you don't  want to hear it. There's no shame in  that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too late for plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never thought I'd hear Ray Gibson  say that. Hell with you then. You'd  only slow me down anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns away as Claude walks off. A DODDERING INMATE st nearby slurping on Jell-O. His robe hangs open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man, cover that shit up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Disgusted, Ray discards his own Jell-O. He pulls out his  daddy's pocket watch and checks the time. The little  mechanical tune nags at him. He snaps the lid shut and  considers the watch resting in the palm of his hand.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED
dialogues.text: Sequence omitted from original script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The building is dark. But then, through a first-floor win we see the unmistakable orange glow of a fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ALARM BLARES as the place fills with smoke. Wearing a  robe and slippers, Nurse Humphries runs among the prisone helping them out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coughing and disheveled, Ray emerges onto the lawn pushin Willie in the wheelchair. As other prisoners evacuate the building, Ray looks around for Claude, but he doesn't see him. Nurse Humphries takes a quick head count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is everyone here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, where's Claude? I don't see  Claude!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stay calm, Ray. We'll find him.  Claude! Has anyone seen Claude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must still be in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grimly, Ray starts toward the burning infirmary. Nurse  Humphries holds him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for the firemen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll be too late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't go in there, Ray! You'll  never make it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going in for him. He'd do the  same for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray shakes her off and runs up the steps, disappearing in the burning building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray dodges flames as he presses into the inferno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nurse Humphries, Willie and the rest of the inmates watch grimly as flames engulf the building. Nobody could surviv this blaze. From the highway comes the siren wail of  approaching fire engines. But it's too late. Sparks erupt into the night sky as the roof collapses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire trucks pull away from the smoldering ruins. A local  REPORTER interviews witnesses. INVESTIGATORS comb through the wreckage, making notes. COUNTY CORONERS pull a couple gurneys from the back of their van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Superintendent Bill Burke is led through the destruction a FIRE INSPECTOR. They approach the coroners as they fini zipping up two body bags.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did it start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably old wires. The place was a  tinderbox just waiting to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we should have torn this old  building down a long time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gibson made it this far before he  was probably overcome by smoke. From  the look of things, Banks never even  made it out of bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burke watches solemnly as the coroners wheel the bodies p him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jake and Leon shake their heads and look at the two fresh graves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you really bummed me out. That's  a terrible story. (looking at Jake) Nigger, you crying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, no! I just got something in my  eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright for a man to cry once  in awhile. Just don't make a habit  of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Willie, what was Claude's plan,  anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing to it, really. Claude figured  they could steal a couple of bodies  from the morgue. They got a couple  of crackers working there don't know  their asses from their elbows. Then  they was gonna set fire to the  infirmary and make it look like those  bodies was them that got stuck inside.  Claude figured during the commotion,  it wouldn't be too hard to slip onto  one of the fire trucks and hang tight  until it rolled right on out of here  in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young inmates share a look, then glance into the grav then look back at Willie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you think it didn't work?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never said it didn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leon and Jake do the arithmetic. You can almost hear the  gears grinding under the strain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You trying to tell us that's not Ray  and Claude in those boxes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Willie starts to chuckle and sets his electric wheel chai on auto-pilot, leaving the young inmates to guess at the  truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think about that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that old man lost his marbles  about a hundred years ago. Come on,  let's get this over with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They pick up their shovels and go back to work burying th caskets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA MOVES PAST a FIREMAN hosing down the truck, pa another group of soot-stained FIREMEN eating breakfast, a pauses in front of two lockers. A couple of FIREMEN emerg from the showers wrapped in towels and open their lockers They share a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the room) Alright, which of you hambones took  our clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scalpers sell tickets. Vendors hawk souvenirs. Fans strea up from the subway and through the gates. Somebody is sin "The Star-Spangled Banner."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the middle of a capacity crowd, a VENDOR fixes two hot dogs and passes them to a KID at the end of an aisle. The kid passes them to the MAN next to him, and so on down th line. The CAMERA FOLLOWS the hot dogs from face to face, some o some young, some black, some white -- it's New York City, after all -- and finally the hot dogs arrive in a pair of old, calloused black hands. Ray passes one of the dogs to Claude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't eat this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the hell not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw that hot dog guy in the bathroom  urinating. He didn't wash his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Claude glance around confused as the wave rolls  through their section of the bleachers. What the fuck? Cl inspects his hot dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just put some mustard on it and eat  it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't get ketchup?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme that damn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray snatches back the hot dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I gonna eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is suddenly young again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have my ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude takes the ice cream. He, too, is suddenly young ag

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other and share a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell of a day for a ballgame, huh,  Claude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell of a day, Ray. Yankees are on  fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Claude pops the top on his ice cream. Suddenly, they are  both old again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this ain't gonna work either.  It's half chocolate, half vanilla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're touching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA begins to pull back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't eat that ice cream right  now, I'm gonna strangle you until  you are completely dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? You and what army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next thing, you're gonna be  complaining about the seats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, if you must know, they could  be closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn, I shoulda let Spanky Johnson  drown you in the river when I had  the chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Pipe downs" etc. from the people around them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing around) I know you're not talking to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, he's on medication...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA PULLS BACK as the arguing continues, just like the old days. MUSIC UP.
